description:
Why do I keep coming back to this place? The filling to crust ratio for their chicken pies and beef curry horns just gets worse and worse. But damn if the crust isn't good. 

Their Danish Fruit Puffs $2.45 are so pretty I'd serve them at a dinner party.
author: Julia C.

description: The breads, pastries, and sandwiches at Sheng Kee are great.  My all-time favorite is the Summer Romance pastry that's made with cream cheese and blueberries (I believe!).  I can get my pastry and coffee for about $3 which is amazing (compared to lesser quality pastries from Starbucks at double the price).  The employees are always very kind and the bakery itself is always very clean and well kept.  The ONLY thing I wish they would change is their coffee station.  They use thermoses (instead of the large, heated steel containers) and only have one kind of coffee.  They are great tho!
author: Sofia G.

description:
Not too bad baked goods. I've been to the one in the East bay on several occasions. 

I didn't realize they had Egg Tarts so I had to go in here and try one for myself and you know what ? It's wasn't that bad. I have them listed below in my Egg Tart rankings. 

I recently embarked on a completely pointless quest to rank places that sell Egg Tart...yes Egg Tart. Obviously given the nature of the food most of these places are in SF or Oakland Chinatown. 

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews

When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. If you're curious, I have rankings for Boba, Bakeries and Ramen as well (random right?).  I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places. 

1 Mr.Bread
2 Golden Gate Bakery
3 Yummy Bakery 
4 New Hollywood Bakery
5 Ruby King Bakery
6 Napolean Super Bakery
7 Sheng Kee Bakery 
8 Wonder Food Bakery 
9 Sum Yee Pastry
10 Grand Mission Donuts and Bakery
author: Rod M.

description:
There is a good variety of items here, more cakes and savory items than other bakeries. It's fairly priced. There's not really any service here since it's get it yourself and pay.

Most stuff looked dry and not to my liking, just kinda plain. But I selected the green tea muffin, which is just a fluffy cake in the shape of a fat muffin. And a lotus cookie, which is alright.
author: Spencer H.

description:
The gleaming lights of Sheng Kee always make my head turn whenever I walk by it. OK, OK! it's also the enticing cake slices, pineapple buns and other Chinese pastries they have displayed.

I honestly * PREFER * Schuberts for their cakes, but my co workers really like their sweets here. I've had their fruit tarts on several occasions and their pineapple buns are always a reliable staple. I do have to mention that naming it pineapple bun is a slight disappointment, as it only looks like a pineapple, but doesn't actually contain any fruit. 

Their fruit tart has perky fresh fruits on it, but the custard is so blah to me. I'd rather spend the extra money and hightail it to Schuberts.
author: Janice C.

description:
Sheng Kee is THE Taiwanese bakery to go to when you're walking along Irving Street in the SF Sunset District.

If you're new to San Francisco and are looking for good Chinese food, I'll be frank, forget Chinatown. It's an important cultural and historical point, as well as the center for many festivals and great activities, but the truth is that a lot of the absolutely MOUTH-WATERING Chinese restaurants are in the Sunset District (seriously, look up Chinese restaurants with "Outer Sunset, San Francisco, CA" inputted into Yelp's location bar). To be fair, it's not just Chinese cuisine either. Part of this is probably because the Sunset District actually has a pretty dense Asian population.

Sheng Kee is a primarily Taiwanese bakery started by a Taiwanese woman and ran by a Taiwanese family and has a selection that competes with SOGO bakeries. They have around a dozen locations around the Bay Area, including Cupertino and Milpitas. So truth be told, Sheng Kee isn't actually all that new to me. What makes the the San Francisco bakeries so prominent is that they are both located on Irving Street, a road prominent for the delicious Chinese eateries lining a long stretch of it. The one down the street from this one is the FIRST one, established back in the 80's(?), while this one was opened much later on the other end of this stretch of eateries to keep up with demand. Both are conveniently placed so that, while looking for a place to eat or waiting for a table, people can easily stop by to pick up dessert before or after a meal as well as a great place to pick up tomorrow's bread/breakfast/snacks. 

That's what made ME so happy. My friends and I came in on Sunday around 7PM (half an hour before they closed) to pick up desserts for after dinner. Despite it being so late, they still had a decent selection of breads, pastries, cookies, cakes, and cake slices. In fact, they had actually been putting out their last few trays as we got there. Not to mention, the employees were really friendly and helpful. And there was several of us asking her to put this cake or bread in a specific box and putting so-and-so boxes in this or that bag and...Kudos. Thank you SO much.

Location wise, this Sheng Kee is a real hole in the wall place. Overall, actually quite small. But they do have a few small chairs and tables next to the door and in front of the floor-to-ceiling table that are a good fit for one- or two-people parties. Additionally, they have some similar tables in the back as well as a couple of small tables with armchairs, still primarily set up for small parties of one or two. If you have a bigger party, try to claim and push together the smaller tables out in front as there really isn't room to do that in the back.

Parking is...challenging along Irving Street. More likely than not, if you're not taking public transportation, you're gonna have to try the surrounding street parking. If you can and you're lucky, try to grab one of the spots along Irving Street. If THAT doesn't work, be sure to check the street parking on the roads running adjacent to Irving (ex. 9th, 10th, 11th, etc.). My friends and I had parked in the Andronico's Community Market parking lot (turn from Irving onto Funston Ave, it'll be to your left. Turn from Irving onto 14th Ave, it'll be on your right). It's technically only for Andronico's customers only, and we did end up buying some groceries and midnight snacks from them before leaving.

Overall, definitely drop in if you're passing by. If not to sit for a while, then to browse through what they have. It's primarily Taiwanese flavors and kinds of baked goods and snacks, but they're good at blending of familiar and unfamiliar flavors and recognizable pastries/snacks/bread. Or if you ARE familiar with Asian bakeries, breads, and flavors, then it's just a matter of a decent, convenient neighborhood Chinese bakery providing for your craving and needs.
author: Christine L.

description:
Always clean, always well-stocked with sweet and savory baked goods, we'll pop into Sheng Kee (translates to "For a Living") for an occasional treat.

The store is partially self-serve: You grab a cafeteria-style plastic tray and line it with wax paper and take one of the many clean tongs hanging by the trays and make your selections from behind the hinged vitrines.

I didn't notice if they have Pandan cakes but they do have Asian treats like hot dog bao (3 different kinds, basically a hot dog baked into a delicious, chewy, egg-y bun); chocolate cream bun, croissants, fruit danish and pain au chocolat. 

They have at least 30 varieties of baked goods from savory to sweet at very reasonable prices. 

You return to the counter to order coffee, hot chocolate or a drink. The counter staff boxes & rings up your goodies.

They have a cozy amount of seating towards the rear of the store but it seems most customers have "to-go" orders.

There are four things I value about Sheng Kee: The store is über clean; the variety and quality of baked goods are appealing; the price point is reasonable and the staff is always polite.

Aside from the calories, there's everything to like about Sheng Kee.

In business for 40 years, started by a mama trying to support her family, this growing chain has locations all over the Bay Area and in Southern California.

Way to go, Mama Bear! We like your business very much and will continue to support Sheng Kee.
author: Jennifer O.

description: The buns were so dry. The filling so minimal. The store layout is so awkward, it leaves more to be desired. Unfortunately, the buns were still as disappointing as they were during my visit a year ago. I swear the location in Berkeley is much better. Unsure about why this one is struggling so much to produce quality products. It's a shame.
author: J P.

description: After a stop at Perilla, had a craving for something sweet. Made a stop here and got the green tea mousse which was good and inexpensive. Picked up a mango mousse  and Portuguese tart for later too.
author: Sunil R.

description: I like coming for their fish sandwich or their egg tarts but they really need to have better boxes,not just rectangle boxes, it don't fit into any bag without the eggtarts or pastries sliding everywhere. They should carry some square boxes like most bakeries, makes carrying and putting in bags a lot better. Taking a star off for not having better boxes.
author: Jen M.

description:
This place reminds me of the bakeries back in 626/LA although on the pricier end --obviously to keep up with the SF prices. My friend wanted to stop by for some pastries as I simply browsed around. I noticed a lot of unique pastries and even sandwiches, which I wonder if it's as good as it looks. Just before we were going to walk out, I noticed their variety of egg tarts from portuguese to cheese, but was the most intrigued about their flavored tarts. I decided to grab all three flavors: green tea, mocha, and cheese ($2.50 each). Too bad I had them hours later when it was cold, so wasn't as great as it could've been. I did enjoy the flavors, especially the cheese one though. The breading is thick though.

Note: Credit card has a $10 minimum or else there's a 50 cents charge.
author: Cindy Z.

description: I cannot come down Irving without stopping at Sheng Kee Bakery.  The treats here are not only pleasing to look at, but they taste great without being overly sweet/sugary.  Grab a tray, a sheet of wax paper and a pair of tongs-then go crazy!  The lunch items (shredded pork bun, curry beef bun, pastry with embedded hot dogs) are in the bins facing the cash register.  The pineapple redbean bun ($1.75) is light and fluffy until you get to the red bean goodness in the center!  Danish fruit boat ($2.45) looks too good to eat-but don't miss out on the flakiness in bottom of the boat-it melts in your mouth.  The custard that holds the fruit in the boat is perfectly matched to the fruit (strawberries & blueberries today)-not too sweet but a thick custard to contrast the flaky layers under it.
author: Molly M.

description: This is a good bakery to use the public restroom. The restroom is clean and very nice! Great place to stop by if you are shopping from Pineapple Bakery and want to use the bathroom after drinking the great iTea.
author: Kevin R.

description: Unfortunately I couldn't give 4 stars. The customer service isn't too great. I'm not a picker customer but when I specially asked for a box and I need a knife to cut the bigger size pastries into smaller bite size, I didn't expect to ask her 3 times. After asking a third time, I got an annoying look. I didn't even ask her to do the cutting. I just need a knife so I can cut it myself. Sheesh...
author: Jen L.

description:
Cakes are delicious and their Tiramisu are the heaven!! But...
Never Order Online. Apparently they never checked their online order. 
So we got to the Bakery to pick up the cake for my friend's birthday and they didn't have our cake ready! It took us over one hour to pick up the cake from the other Sheng Kee.
Do Not Order Online at this place!
author: Ata R.

description: Got my favorite pastry but it was a disappointment. I usually go to the other location nearby. I decided to give this one a shot since it closer to where I live. The pastry was soft and underbaked. I think I'll save my stomach for another location next time.
author: Diana N.

description:
Have you ever went for a walk and felt like a nice refreshing drink and then you see a sign for some cheap fresh watermelon juice? Well, that's how I found this place! The drinks were super cheap but I can't remember exactly how much they were, however it might be around $2.50 per drink with pearls or jelly. Their pastries inside too were inexpensive. It's self serve and there are tables inside and at the back that turns into a patio.

Go for: cheap snacks

Don't go for: ...you get what you pay for...
author: John V.

description:
Stopped by here late one Sunday because we were craving some bread, and there was still a reasonable selection around 5PM. Typical Asian bakery with sweet and savory options, larger loaves of bread and cakes. I really wanted to try the Green Tea Mochi Danish, but they were out of those by that time.

Instead, we got a DONUT TWIST ($1.90), which was really twisted bread with some raisins and sweet coconut layered inside (definitely not a donut), and a loaf of EGG BREAD ($3.29). Both were soft and lightly sweetened, as is typical of Asian breads. Neither were particularly special but will satisfy your bread cravings.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Sheng Kee is a Hong Kong-style bakery with pastries that deliciously combine Chinese and western styles at extremely reasonable prices. It's a chain the Bay Area and the stores vary in size and quality. They offer both sweet and savory pastries.

This one in the inner Sunset is outstanding for quality, selection, friendliness of staff, and atmosphere. The seating areas are bright, clean, and spacious. The pastries are always fresh and the Hong Kong milk tea is well-done with a balance of strong tea and sweetened condensed milk.
author: Greg T.

description: If you are in Inner Sunset and want to get something sweet or get a quick bite, come here. There are many pastries, food, drinks, cakes, and more for very reasonable prices. There is plenty of staff so checking out is quick and easy. Totally worth it.
author: Deb K.

description: The bread is not fresh at all. Looks like sold for few days, probably won't go back again.
author: Lina L.

description:
Bought a cheese cake last night for our Christmas party.

Everyone loves their cake so much.

Taste very fresh!
author: Mack A.

description: The food is definitely worth the price. I used to go here during my high school days. The staff is friendly as well. The environment is quite welcoming and clean. Since I'm not in the area anymore, I can't go here so it's a shame. I can no longer get fat on their pastries
author: Sandra N.

description:
Been going to the various locations of this chain for years.  Food quality is usually good.  

Got 2 buns this morning.  One was significantly softer than the other harder-crust type.  They were put in one bag with the softer one on the bottom and the cashier even rolled down the paper bag several folds, adding to the pressure on the bag. I did not notice how she put the more delicate one below the more sturdy, heavier one until I got home, after other errands. By then, my cream bun was crushed.  The fluffy lightness of the bun was no longer.
I expected bakeries to be aware and respectful of the delicacy of their fresh baked goods.  She should never have put the soft bun under another.

I hope this review will be read by the bakery so that they will train their workers better, and the workers there will take more pride in their products to package them with more care.
author: Lisa T.

description:
I've been to Sheng Kee locations before, just not this location until now. Since I work nearby, I decided to come by to get something quick to eat. I walk in and am greeted by the workers. 
Then I grabbed a tray and a parchment paper and began looking at the selection of buns. Some of the cabinets weren't full, so I'm guessing they sell certain buns quick. After looking around for a minute, I settled on their bun of the week: the green onion bun. It was a decent size and I didn't want a bun too sweet anyways, so it was perfect! The bun was really good and flavorful from the green onion. I'm not sure if the bun of the week is always going to be 99 cents but I think it's pretty cool deal. Definitely will be back!
author: Coco L.

description:
Do you know where to get those cheap birthday candles near 9th & Irving in a pinch?  Neither did I, but I thought it would be much easier than it was.

I was headed to either my niece's or my nephew's birthday party, and my brother asked if I could pick up some candles for the cake.  Nothing special, just those twisty multicolored waxy things we all remember from our childhood and that always seem to be lying around in random junk drawers, along with Elmer's glue, brassy thumbtacks (how long have those been there?), and old phone cords.

I searched through all the drawers in my flat, but I couldn't find any cake candles.  (We had candles, but they were either votives or full-on Liberace-candelabra deals.  There was nothing small.)  I didn't feel like getting ripped off by Bi-Rite, so I hopped on the bus and figured I'd pick something up in the Inner Sunset.

My first stop was Golden Bear (https://www.yelp.com/biz/golden-bear-trading-company-san-francisco-3), but they barely have what they're supposed to, let alone candles, and really, who would want to waste time on actually stocking a market with things you can actually sell rather than providing your would-be customers with tons and tons of useless empty space?  I mean, everyone knows that San Franciscans like to pay too much for small portions, to have nowhere to sit, and when they do find places to sit to be uncomfortable.  It's all about standing in line and overpaying, right?

Next was Royal Food Store (https://www.yelp.com/biz/royal-food-store-san-francisco).  No candles there, but at least they were helpful.  They suggested Rexall on 9th & Irving.

I headed over there (https://www.yelp.com/biz/reliable-rexall-a-compounding-pharmacy-san-francisco-2) and was prepared to pay too much for the candles, but I knew they would have them.  I've always found what I'm looking for there, although it's usually shoddy and overpriced.  I searched the aisles in vain until one of the teenage-looking cashiers asked what I was looking for and told me they did not have candles.  She suggested Sheng Kee Bakery across Irving, and I was prepared either to walk all the way to Andronico's and pay through the nose for some organic beeswax or to just give up and show up to the party defeated, the person solely responsible for not ensuring the birthday cake was properly covered in grade-school saliva.

It was just across the street, so I figured I would give it a shot and have a funny story to tell.  I walked in, and I was surprised by how gleaming and bright and inviting the place was.  I would definitely have to come back and try something from here.  I didn't even look for anything; I just sheepishly got the cashier's attention and asked whether they carried birthday-cake candles.

Prepared to be told no, I was almost turning around when he asked which size I wanted.

"What do you mean?"

"We've got little ones, bigger ones, the numbers, whatever you need."

I looked at where he was pointing, and there were, indeed, different candles right by the cash register.

"Do people buy a lot of these?"

"All the time," he said.

And so I succeeded, eventually.  Thanks, Sheng Kee.
author: John S.

description: I was very impressed by the cake this place serves. My friends brought me Mocha Walnut cake for my birthday and I just couldnt stop eating it because it was just so good. I kept eating it until I finished. That was my first experience at Sheng Kee Bakery. Then my friend went back to San Francisco again and I really wanted the cake so I asked him to bring me another one. When I got the cake, I was really excited. So I tried a little bit of it and the taste was NOT the same like the first time so I thought I would try it in the morning maybe I was to full and that is why I did not enjoy it. What turns out is that the cake has gone bad!!!!! I took pictures to save it. Then I called them to ask about why it was bad and all they said was come back and will give you a piece of cake!!! thats it..
author: Reta B.

description: Great Chinese bakery in the Sunset. Enjoyed the green tea mochi crossaint, pineapple bun, walnut bread and fresh egg custard. Do wish their pastries were warm/heated though. Bring cash!
author: Chelsea W.

description:
If you are around the area and want a place to study or to get some baked goods, come by.

For a bakery in SF, I would think it would be really small, but they have a good amount of space for seating and such. The bathroom is actually outside, but they were pretty clean. Props to them! Some seating outside as well.

We went close to closing time, but the staff was still friendly to us even though we came so late (we're one of thoseeee peopleee) 

I got one of the sweet buns and thought it was just okay. There wasn't a lot of options compared to other asian bakeries in SJ/cupertino area. I rather go to Paris Baguette or 85 degree.

Not bad, but not AMAZING.
author: Martin N.

description:
My Taiwanese friends introduced me to this bakery.  They have one of the best bread I ever tasted. The whole wheat bread is great here. I try to avoid the other types of bread like the regular white bread or raisin or red bean or other as they won't last long. They're so delicious. 

Both locations in the sunset have consistent high quality pastries. 

This bakery adds a nice Asian touch to the lifestyle of city of San Francisco. The atmosphere, the service, the quality and everything is great.

I will miss this place for sure.
author: Ahmad A.

description: Bring your Kids and let them choose their pastries . Grab a small try and choose from an array of good cakes , pastries and Sandwiches....
author: Donovan L.

description: $3.75 for a tea with milk & a pastry. More seating then Starbucks, Free Wifi and friendly staff. Can't beat it.... The Hong Kong Style pastries don't hurt.  Love it. Going to be my hangout.
author: Leung T.

description:
I don't know whether I'm getting old or becoming a tea snob (probably a little bit of both), but I'm just not so excited anymore about spending $2 on sweet boba milk tea or buttery Asian pastries.  

[THE TEA]

Tea quality is definitely not bad--they brew their own tea so it is a huge step up from all the powder places frequented by high schoolers who don't know better (Quickly, Tpumps, etc... plus Sheng Kee service is just as Quick and the ambiance is just as Pumped).  The main problem is that everything is pre-mixed, so you can't request light sugar unless you ask them  to dilute it.  Otherwise, $2 for milk tea, boba option included, is quite a deal.  I especially like the HK milk tea, which features a supratherapeutic dose of caffeine.

[THE BAKED GOODS]

All their pastries are deliciously buttery with a soft, flaky texture.  There are quite a lot of choices encompassing from savory to snack to dessert, traditional Chinese to fusion to western, and everything in between!  They also have a wide variety of cakes and candles, so it's a convenient go-to for special occasions because colorful glossy Sheng Kee cakes look so much better than the boring ones from Safeway.

[CONCLUSION]

Very good prices (when is the last time you got anything from Starbucks or Peet's for $2 or less?!), decent quality, and addictively tasty, just very sweet!  (I once got a milk tea and a green tea mochi pastry for lunch.... though I like both, when you have both in one meal it tastes like diabetes)
author: Edna C.

description:
My mom's satisfaction was all that mattered today, so my review will be based on her happiness. 

It was her birthday, and I decided to buy a cake from Sheng Kee. I got the Mocha Walnut Cake for $20.95. My mom loved the look of the cake- she couldn't stop mentioning how pretty the cake was. The cake also had a lovely coffee tang with a great deal of walnuts. If you worry that this cake is too sweet, it's not! Only the chocolate was sweet, which there was actually a lot of on the cake. There was also a lot of mocha cream- not too sweet but there was just way too much in my opinion. It's good, just too much. 

Any way, the workers were nice and even offered a little birthday sign to put on the cake! 

Come here for future birthday cakes to any one special in your life! They deserve it.
author: Wendy T.

description:
Pretty good boba tea served here, though it is pre-sweetened. I prefer mine to have little to no sweetness added. If you're pressed for time, however, and are in need of relief for your bubble tea craving, this will place will do in a pinch! It is incredibly inexpensive and centrally located, so even if you don't have a lot of extra time, you can still enjoy some boba or a snack or pastry. Though be warned--Everything here is really cheap and you may walk out spending more than you had meant to, with way more sweets than you had meant to! 

The baked goods are hit or miss, I've gotten some good tasting things but also some very odd, dry, or bland tasting things. Don't go overboard and choose wisely!
author: Megan D.

description:
I don't usually come here but once in a while they have unique selection of bread. Green tea mochi cruffins which is a croissant in a muffin form. Upside down curry cheese bread. Taro cream rolls. Puffy cheese cake. Now they have boba drinks . 

Portuguese egg tart 3:5
It's creamy but the shell 's texture isn't flaky with multiple layers. Flavor is alright not too amazing . 

Green tea mochi croissant muffin 5:5
Very creative , it's like eating mochi and muffin with a croissant texture . Green tea tastes like mung bean more. 

Pineapple custard bun 1:5
It's not a pineapple bun. Doesn't have the yellow layer on top that taste sweet. The custard is ok.
author: Miri L.

description: We called to place an order here for 50 buns for an event the following day. On the next day, we called again just to make sure they have everything set up and the guy was super friendly! They had our order ready to pick up within 15 minutes. Highly recommend!
author: Kim V.

description: I really liked my selection until checkout. I had to purchase a drink to meet their 10 card min and there was a miscommunication on what I wanted. Instead of correcting it she told me it was my fault so I just left feeling pissed as fuck. Don't go here.
author: Beverly K.

description: Great prices! I bought three pastries for less than $5! Grabbing the tongs and placing on your tray reminds me of bakeries in Tokyo.
author: Lukish D.

description:
I absolutely love this bakery. 

Everything I've had here is delicious and surprisingly inexpensive. They even have bogo sales!

There is a big variety of savory pastries, sweet pastries and sandwiches, as well as a case full of beautiful fancy cakes in front of the store..They make the best latte, using Peet's coffee. Always good music on the radio.

They have tables in the big picture window in front of the store so you can sit and people watch, and they have booths in the back which are quiet and private,

The place is super clean. friendly  and cheery

A lovely bakery with great baked goods and a variety of beverages, run by very nice people.
author: Sharon J.

description: The Portuguese egg tarts are the best things here! They taste almost exactly like the ones I've had in Lisbon. I've tried other things, but everything else has been average. Great service every time I've been there.
author: Alyssa P.

description:
TL;DR?? Pretty decent! I am fairly and positively surprised I ran into Sheng Kee by a stroke of luck but this place fares well for a delicious Asian bakery. Definitely recommend- clean, fairly priced, and great service!

Ambiance, Prices: A
Food Quality, Service, Location: B

I was leaving UCSF and wanted to stop by a Bank of America to withdraw cash in case of toll. As I was leaving BoA, I noticed Sheng Kee was next to it! A purely happy coincidence :) I headed straight in as the place looked alluring with its delicious baked goods. I figured that if I was leaving the city during rush hour (Thursday 4:30PM) that I was not going to brave the storm snack-less!

In I go through the door, the store interior is very airy and spacious. Directly in front of me is the cashier/bakery counter and to my left were the dining area and product shelves. Their selection and variety of baked goods were not as many as I had anticipated, perhaps because I have been spoiled by 85C? They also offered boba, coffe, and teas for cheap (less than $3). Regardless, they had the usual breads of hot dog, bacon, taro, bbq pork, etc. and additionally some new kinds such as milk and chocolate roll. I ended up buying 3 BBQ pork buns, 1 hot dog bun, and 1 green tea mochi bun. Total price came to $7.13 which was pretty cheap! The cashier was very cheery and pleasant and offered to place my buns in a box ;) Good solid experience. Nothing extraordinary but thankfully not a disappointing disaster.
author: Donna T.

description:
I enjoy Sheng Kee Bakery because much like most Chinese Bakeries, the food items are less sweet but not bland and still tasty and fresh compared to their non-Asian counterparts like the stuff you get in the supermarkets or other desert places, so it's lighter and more delicious as well as priced well.

Parking can be difficult, but not impossible depending on your karma.  There's meters and street parking in the area.
author: Rick S.

description:
To all you goobers out there waiting in line for hours at Tartine for a croissant...here's the scoop: for a third of the price and no line at Sheng Kee you can get the most amazing buttery croissants that melt in your mouth.  On top of that, they have an array of buns and brioches topped with cheese, green onion, bacon etc... They have the best little custard tarts, fluffy cakes and yummy fruit pies that are light and tasty.  Ok, so no it's not artisan bread or organic flour but it's delicious pastries and sandwiches at affordable prices.
Now that the secret is out, try it!

Goodness
author: Monkey B.

description: Horrible service and unsanitary food area.  I went there on a Friday night trying to get some food for the next morning.  At 7pm, I am surprised there are still a lot of bun left.  I should have known that is not a good sign.  I picked 2 buns from first tier and 2nd tier.  When I get to 3rd tier, I saw a bug flying around in the case.  Immediately, I decide not to get anything from 3rd.  What I should have done is to not get the ones I have already got, but I figured it should be fine.  When I try to get ring up using credit card, the casher told me it's $10 min.  I was fine with it but the casher was giving me attitude and took my money without saying anything or even provide a receipt.  Next day, after eating the breakfast I bought, I start to regret getting it in the first place because I got stomachache..
author: Joyce T.

description:
Pretty standard Asian bakery with a good assortment of both the sweet (brioche, blueberry middle buns) and the savory (fried chicken sandwiches and ham and mushroom buns). The selection is smaller than an 85 or a Paris Baguette but they have the basics like the hot dog bun, moon cakes, chocolate bread, and brioche bun(my fave) so you'll be sure to satisfy a light bread craving.

What was surprising was that this place had similar items to an 85.

Good back area with a lot of comfortable chairs and tables for work!
author: Angela H.

description:
The selection of bread and pastries is limited compared to other Sheng Kee's I've visited in East Bay or South Bay. And the quality of bread here is actually pretty disappointing for a Sheng Kee. It never tastes fresh. I've tried both the butter bread and brioche bread and it's kind of hard and stale, even if I eat it on the same day. After sticking 'em in the fridge for a couple of days, they're no longer that edible. I'm not sure if this means they use less preservatives compared to other places like 85C (a butter bread from there is still soft after microwaving 3-4 days after purchasing, so long as you refrigerate it)...or if it's because they're selling bread that was baked a couple of days ago. I'm betting on the latter since bread from other Sheng Kee bakeries taste better.

With that said, the fried pork and fried fish sandwiches are really amazing and their cakes look good. The layout of the store is also very impressive - it's clean and bright and there's actually free WiFi and some seating in the back. I think it'd make a great place to study. They also serve Peet's coffee if you like your goodies with some caffeine (I do). 

Finally, they sell Beijing yogurt. It's really hard for me to find this stuff so I was thrilled out of my mind that they have 'em.
author: Tiffany H.

description: I had some of the pastries, but honestly not the best.  It's a great hole-in-the wall place and its super cheap.  So definitely great for the price, but if you're willing to splurge go to another bakery.
author: Nisha S.

description: I love this place! Has a large assortment of pastries, cakes, and other goodies! It's also spacious and the top 40s music played overhead is so soothing and puts you in a great mood! They also serve honey boba now too which I always like as an add-on to the drinks I order.  The staff is always so friendly and helpful too! Great atmosphere.
author: Phan ..

description: The place is great fairly clean place, except their couches are always dirty and needs cleaning....They need to go to leather, vinyl or other material to keep the nasties off.  Since i complained last year, they put cloth covers over the seats, but the covers are dirty with spills and they need to clean them regularly.  Get vinyl or leather and please clean seats....at least with leather or vinyl, I can wipe the seat down myself in needed, but its the main reason why I think people don't frequent here as much..... I like it here, but its not comfortable to see dirty seats.  I took of two stars off because this is the second time I have complained in last year.  I would come more often and I am sure others would too rather than Starbucks.  Just got to up the game a little.  Shengkee in Taiwan has better set up.
author: tom c.

description:
I wanted to buy an Asian cake for my sister and dad's birthday, which happens to be on the same day. Walking into the bakery, I was a little confused at first because of their layout. The cake display and the register was in front of me and the pastries were located on my left. What's interesting is their method of selling pastries. You have to grab a tray near the door, place a tray cover on the tray, and grab tongs. Then you go to the pastry display case, open the window, and use the tongs to grab the pastry you want. 

Most of the pastries are typical Asian ones. But they do have different variations. I ended up getting the almond croissant, chocolate croissant, and pork sung green onion bun. The almond croissant was pretty good. The outer part of the pastry was flaky and the almond filling was flavorful. The chocolate croissant was good, but I think it would have been better if the chocolate was more melty. I really liked the pork sung green onion bun because it was different. The pastry was both salty and sweet. And the mix of flavors made it appealing to me. 

I went up to the counter to pay. The guy at the register wrapped everything up for me. I also wanted to get the fruit basket cake which had a mix of fruits. The fruit arrangement on top of the cake was very pretty. The strawberries, kiwi, and peaches made the cake look like a summery artwork. I was a little disappointed that the fruits in the middle of the cake were frozen though I wasn't surprised. My family didn't eat the cake until 6 hours later, but the fruits were still frozen.

Overall, I thought the pastries and cake were good, but a little pricy compared to other Chinese bakeries. I'll definitely return to try some of their other pastries.
author: Andrea G.

description:
This place smells heavenly! This is the place to go for yummy Chinese pastries, but stay away from their American desserts (e.g., cheesecake). The buns, even the savory ones, are really good because the breads are so nice and fluffy. 

This is also a very big bakery because there are a lot of seats in the back. The workers are also really nice.
author: Rachel H.

description: Stopped in for a loaf of the raisin bread and was not disappointed. They have a large selection of baked goods: sweet, savor, breads, cakes, etc. As is typical of Asian bakeries, the prices are probably lower than you'd find elsewhere.
author: Selena L.

description:
Really cute little bakery, super bright and airy inside, with a pretty decent selection of Chinese baked goods. Perusing the shelves of pastries with a tray and tongs in hand reminded me of the way it's done in a panaderia picking out pan dulce. Premade sandwiches and delicious looking fruit cakes are at the front of the bakery, as well, and you can get boba drinks, too.

I went with the pineapple bun, a mocha almond bun that looked pretty good, the BBQ pork pastry, and a chicken salad sandwich from the deli case. With a bottle of water my total came out to a little over $9. 

The sandwich was really good, with a ton of fruit mixed in with the chicken, between a tasty raisin bread. The pineapple bun was good except for the crust, which was too hard, especially compared to ones I've had from other Chinese bakeries where everything was incredibly soft. The BBQ pork pastry I had mixed feelings about; there were way too many layers of pastry wrapped around the BBQ pork filling, so much so it stuck to the roof of your mouth and masked the flavor of the pork. And yet, when I managed to taste the pork, it was really good, and the pastry crust was very flaky and buttery, so it was a bit of a mixed bag. The almond mocha bun, however, wasn't that great, as it was a victim of total overkill with the mocha cream filling. Way too rich, and because the bun was so soft (a plus, at least) it didn't have a whole lot of substance and just became a big mess.

I would definitely want to try the things I liked here again and come back to try some of those great looking cakes, get a boba, and taste some of the other baked goods, but I'm not so sure if it's worth a special trip from the East Bay. If I was in the area, then I'd come back, but for now I'll stick to the bakeries that are much closer.
author: Angela M.

description:
Turns out there are two Sheng Kee bakeries on Irving! 

Sheng Kee Bakery has a wide selection of sweet and savory and plain breads and pastries in Asian and European styles. They also serve sandwiches, soups, and Peet's Coffee. 
Each time I have gone to Sheng Kee, the quality has been consistently good. Their BBQ pork buns are always solid (as in reliable and good, not rock hard), and especially delicious when they're hot out of the oven. I like their sweet buns such as the taro bun and the yam bun. Their chocolate croissants and turnovers are also top notch. 
The staff are always friendly and helpful. The prices are well marked and quite reasonable. While, for example, the pork buns here are $1.80 instead of more traditional dim sum bakeries which may sell for $0.75, the quality is more consistent. 
The bakery does feel like a chain, which it is, but the quality makes it a good neighborhood staple.
author: Allxie C.

description:
Typical Asian bakery with a somewhat limited selection of freshly baked goods but a wide variety of special cakes.

I do appreciate that they run weekly specials, such as reduced price mocha rolls. Normal prices are a bit steep compared to the Asian bakeries back home.

I took a fellow Yelper's advice and opted for the GREEN TEA MOCHI DANISH, $1.89 (http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/At6Q1wPtUaKYQPGOqMjCgg/l.jpg). The pastry itself was familiarly flaky and chewy, lightly sweet and topped with almonds. The interesting part was the very sweet green tea mochi that had a strange tart apple flavor to it (http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Im6v5CbnIrBRzPdSnvvCCQ/l.jpg). There was a small layer of milky white mochi, which I preferred. It took some time, but the pastry eventually grew on me.

Also, their special cakes will run between $18.95 - $23.95. A TIRAMISU CAKE is $19.95, $24.50 after tax. I believe all cakes comes with an optional free custom icing message written on a white chocolate piece. Oh, and if you can't commit to a huge cake, or are watching your waistline, small cake slices run between $1.99 - $3.19, with some tarts at $4.99.

UPDATE (12/3/13):

At the end of the day, they may have BOGO free pastries by the cash register. Steeeaaal.

MILK BUN ($1.99; http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sheng-kee-bakery-san-francisco-5?select=7njlz4sXY7AY_uufoCF3gA#7njlz4sXY7AY_uufoCF3gA): Get this. Not only is it the size of your head, but it's also super fluffy and full of light buttermilk flavor. Plus, the crumble on top is delish.

TARO PASTRY ($2; http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sheng-kee-bakery-san-francisco-5?select=y3f9KQCK0DrjYzGDjY-2qw#9gw2HwjtVGDW1BsPxdZc5Q): Flaky and stuffed with mochi and taro paste. Could be considered dry by some standards.

CHEESE PUFF ROLL SLICE ($1.55; http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sheng-kee-bakery-san-francisco-5?select=y3f9KQCK0DrjYzGDjY-2qw#y3f9KQCK0DrjYzGDjY-2qw): Pass. I liked the inside sponge cake (Asian bakeries do sponge cake so right), but I wasn't a big fan of the cheesy lard border--too crusty and lardy.

DATE PASTRY ($1.99; http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sheng-kee-bakery-san-francisco-5?select=y3f9KQCK0DrjYzGDjY-2qw#qnz6nk5eXkSQ-iFALj6qAA): Dating a pastry? Nah, wouldn't last long. Reminiscent of the Asian dried prune snack but very dense in texture. Not bad, but not great.

Also, I really need to come here more often for their $2 sandwiches. One could easily serve as a light meal, two if you're craving more. Lunch for less than $5 is ridic.
author: Adele F.

description:
I like this place! It's clean, cheap, and tasty.

They have a refrigerated area with drinks, salads, and sandwiches, as well as the section where you can choose your baked goods. They even have a few tables to sit and enjoy your treats at! And it smells divine inside. If I weren't watching my weight, this place would be a huge problem for me.

I got the taro-pineapple bun, the green tea mochi bun, and the almond croissant.

The taro-pineapple bun was delicious and sweet, but not too sweet. It was soft and tasted better warm. The green tea mochi bun was good too, soft and flaky on the outside and chewy on the inside. It was probably better for those with a sweet tooth. The almond croissant was perfect too. I'd have loved to have it with some coffee.

Overall, great place to visit. If you find yourself in the area, spend a good $5-7 and walk out with a box full of delicious pastries.
author: Danielle S.

description: Custom made birthday cake the same day.  Amazingly fast chinese workers.  If your kids go pick it up, the lady will be nice to put the change in a small plastic bag.  How cute.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Affordable, delectable Asian pastries here. You can get breakfast or lunch here for under $5 or $10, respectively. I usually buy a whole wheat loaf of bread for my parents. It's soft and slightly buttery, and reminds them of Hong Kong bread. For me, I always get the Hong Kong style milk tea ($2). It's a delicious black tea with cream, and I highly recommend it. 

I've bought their cakes twice for my friends' birthdays. I liked the designs of the cakes. Once, we got a strawberry cake shaped like the face of a cute pig. The taste wasn't particularly remarkable or memorable though. Another time, I got a Black Forest currant cake. That tasted very tart (frozen yogurt tart), which I personally liked. If you're someone who's not a fan of tart-tasting foods, this may not be the best cake for you.
author: Joanne K.

description: I love this bakery. The cakes aren't so sweet which I like. They are decorated beautifully. I don't live near this bakery. I only get to eat here when every I'm in the City. But boy is it a treat!!!
author: Dorothy B.

description: Love the egg tart and wish they check the coffee frequently. Thanks for the service Amanda. I'll be back for breakfast
author: Jasper K.

description:
This place is my savior. 

Nothing too crazy, just saved my flaming lips and tongue from a crazy experience at the Craw Station where I ate their dynamite sauce. 

I remembered passing by this Sheng Kee and glanced at a poster about $2.99 for a ham and egg sandwich and a milk tea. SLICK DEAL! If you ever suffered from an idiotic moment of ordering something extremely spicy, whether it is that dynamite sauce I had or extremely spicy curry down the street, milk product is your friend, and milk tea is a perfect example! I've had their almond milk tea, it's actually pretty good for a place whose forte is not milk tea. Their boba is free, and it's quite chewy. It wasn't too hard like undercooked nor too soft like overcooked. With the ham and egg 'wich? Just right for an afternoon tea or an early breakfast. I personally hate mayo, and the only downside is that there's a thick slab of mayo in the ham and egg sandwich. For $2.99, I'll live with it.

I've had a few of their pastries other than the ham and egg 'wich. I've had their egg tart and this strawberry custard croissant http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sheng-kee-bakery-san-francisco-5?select=fuDk9XL9Q-ba3oUhPQFzAw#VGIxNhv30h7Qe0Y2ApEJ1A. They're alright, prettier than its actual taste. Perhaps they weren't fresh out of the oven when I bought them, and I didn't try them until an hour later. The strawberry falls easily, so be careful when you bite into it as you try to get a bit of custard, crust, and strawberry at once. The egg tart is mediocre like everywhere else. I enjoyed its crust though, not extremely oily like at dim sum restaurants, slightly crunchy and not too flaky (personal preference).
author: Connie C.

description:
After a productive day and nice dinner, we came out to find MUNI completely disabled. We were stranded and initially decided to wait it out and duck into Sheng Kee for some dessert.

We shared a slice of their raspberry mousse and strawberry mousse and found them both to be a little old and bland. They were likely sitting in the refrigerator all day so they dried out a bit. Unfortunately we got the short end of this stick but I would come back to give it a try during the day. However, this visit was definitely disappointing.

I'm a big fan of Chinese buns and desserts and it's one of the best ways to start the day. There are many bakeries to choose from so I hope this trip wasn't typical of Sheng Kee. I'll give it another try to confirm soon.

Food: 6/10

Service: 6/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 6/10
author: Joe M.

description:
Came here on a normal Wednesday morning. They were ill-prepared. Nothing was on the racks.  The cashier did not know what was what on the rack behind her. And They can't accept a $50?!?!?! Wtf! What kind of business are these amateurs running?

Update:
The management wrote me about my review and said she reported me to Yelp. What a champ!  Her employer lied to her. I went to the store after it had opened!  She said her employee told her I went there before opening which is a big fat lie.  Amateurs trying to be business and cannot even get the story straight before reporting to Yelp. Avoid at all costs because the "management" doesn't care.
author: William L.

description:
A hot cup of HK milk tea for $2! They also have a selection of basic pre made sandwiches for $4: Vietnamese, turkey cranberry, ham and cheese. 

You can ask for the milk tea at 50% sweet; I think it's perfect this way.
author: Erin J.

description:
Hiding under my rock for the past few weeks I had no idea this space became a Sheng Kee Bakery location until I read about it from a trusty Yelp friend recently.  Once I decided to stop in I can't seem to stop now.  Their selection is quite different than what I'm used to at their other San Francisco location a mere 11 blocks away.  Each time I've visited the new location something different has caught my eye to try.

The staff here is exceptionally friendly and helpful, and they don't bark at me like the older ladies at the other location do from time to time.  I love that the pastries purchased here are carefully packed into boxes.  In addition to some of the more traditional items like baked buns and cake rolls I've tried some not-so-common items also.  Of all the things I've tried there's probably just two items I would not purchase again.

So from savory to sweet and in no particular order here is a sampling of what I've tried so far:

Ham & Mushroom Bun (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TNRY8SId9WzIhRNbodDehA?select=41uDFZI1488oXwtF0JIMCg) - It's like a pizza baked on top of bun dough.  The tomato sauce is thin and tangy and the mushrooms are canned, but the two slices of deli ham were quite generous and in addition to the melty cheese I liked that there was a bit of crunch from strips of onion and green bell pepper within.  This was very good.

Ham & Corn Bun (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TNRY8SId9WzIhRNbodDehA?select=troabOP7XLoBm45pzWfmWQ) - The corn and ham topping was very skimpy on this unlike the ones I enjoy from my neighborhood Fancy Wheat Field Bakery.  I'd pass on these next time.

Hawaiian Bun (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TNRY8SId9WzIhRNbodDehA?select=LJ3ILnNSCeyPcWuxpvRKNg) - If you like Hawaiian pizza chances are you'll like this bun also.  There's no tomato sauce on this, but the generous amount of corn kernels, chopped ham and pineapple pieces all held together by melty cheese is a party in your mouth just waiting to happen.  I only like Hawaiian pizza, but I loved this!

Cheese & Jalapeno French Bread (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TNRY8SId9WzIhRNbodDehA?select=YdJFJz15TfvNOQbj-SrfDA) - The version at Andersen Bakeries is many times better.  The cheese inside the bun was quite generous, but they added a ridiculous amount of salt that simply overpowered both the cheese and the jalapeno.  That's tough to do, but they succeeded.  Blah!!

Blueberry Pound Cake (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TNRY8SId9WzIhRNbodDehA?select=_qwkm2KkHmFHorVfhWdaWQ) - The cake is dense and moist and not very sweet either.  The amount of blueberries within the loaf was very generous.

Puff Pastry Custard Bun (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TNRY8SId9WzIhRNbodDehA?select=fuDk9XL9Q-ba3oUhPQFzAw) - Find a friend and share this with because the puff pastry and the generous amount of custard inside is definitely on the oily and rich side.  I lightly toasted it to make the puff pastry shell crispy.  Could that have been my shortfall?  Had it not been so rich I would have liked it a lot more.

Apple Flan (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TNRY8SId9WzIhRNbodDehA?select=jpNvuo4hJPq32bp5OeLXGA) - I heated this up and served it with some homemade cherry and bourbon ice cream that a good friend passed along.  The flan part could be better both in flavor and consistency.  It was definitely on the gritty side.  I did enjoy the soft, tart apple slices which may have saved this flan.  Great that it's not overly sweet.

So my four stars may appear a bit generous, but they're new and still getting some of their kinks out.  In my future I see myself visiting this location a lot more often than the original location.  A super clean shop and the friendly atmosphere count for something too.  I can't wait to discover more deliciousness on my next visit!
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
Overall a nice place to be at. They have small sitting area inside. As for boba? you can get them here as well. Milk tea, tiger milk tea (mix of milk tea and thai milk tea), thai milk tea, and a few others. Limited as it is a bakery store. 

Their selection is pretty good from cakes to different types of bread. They also have ready to eat sandwiches too if you just want something quick. 

Service has always been nice every time I've been here so far.
author: Corie L.

description:
I love Sheng Kee, all of them. 

This one particularly, they are very clean inside. Which you don't always find. They usually had a full stock of all their items. They have different types of deals all the time, several times a week sometimes. 

They have not only pastries but different types of sandwiches also.

Coffee, tea, etc.

The downside? They only take credit if you spend more than $5. So make sure you bring cash!

They're pretty quick so I think their customer service is good? I'm only ever in and out quick with no problems. Sounds good right?!
author: Elysia M.

description:
This is like the anti-Chinatown bakery. Instead of the chaos and abrupt service you would find in a place like Eastern Bakery on Grant Avenue, there is organization and calm in this serene location on Irving near 9th. It's one of those European-style bakeries where you help yourself to their selection of goodies with a pair of plastic tongs. Most of the pastries are on white trays in well-marked lucite bins, so you can spend as much time as you want perusing the calories. Even though Jamie W. and I just had our shared Ginger Cake with Pumpkin Ice Cream at Park Chow around the corner, we still couldn't help ourselves from browsing.

I ended up getting a couple of things to go. One was a $1.35 Portuguese Custard Tart (see photo). Why? Because I just went to Lisbon last year, and the big treat to buy there is the pastel de nata outside of Jeronimos Monastery in the Belem area. It's similar to the tarts you get at Golden Gate Bakery except the top is browned. Good to know I can find them here since I was popping those in my mouth in Lisbon like nobody's business. The other item I bought was a $2.25 Turkey Sandwich which they put between slices of their extra soft white bread (see photo). It was fine the day after when I brought it to work for lunch. So was the tart. I could use a Sheng Kee Bakery closer to my home but alas, it's good to know it's around.

FOOD - 3 stars...nice eats and treats immaculately presented
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...organized and calm with plenty of pickings
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...very quiet and deferential
TOTAL - 3 stars...definitely worth a stop in the area if you need a little something in your stomach
author: Ed U.

description:
This place is right next to One Medical, so I often schedule any doctor appointments I may need here just so I can come by and have an excuse to also get some breads and cakes. Ohhh, I'm sick...time to get some pineapple buns...you know, that kind of thing. (Not really.)

I came in at around 1030 am, so everything was abundant and warm! Oh my gosh. I should really just go to bakeries early, because there is really nothing like a freshly baked green tea mochi danish. The texture difference is huge. I also picked up a tuna and corn danish for tea later on, which I just ate. Oh man. So good. The tuna didn't have mayo, which is a plus for me and my allergies, and it went really well with my tea here at home. This Sheng Kee location had WAY more things than the one back in Pacifica. Fried fish sandwiches?!!!! Noms.

The service was friendly and quick. The woman behind the cash register asked if I'd like my breads packed separately, since I had some savories and some sweets, and that was a small act I appreciated. I like that they had some tea selections as well. The oolong creama was surprisingly good in that the oolong taste was quite strong.

I'd definitely go back. Maybe next time I won't even wait til I have to visit the doctor.
author: Robbin A.

description: I like their Portuguese custard tart and green tea mochi danish. I bought them to my work, everyone loves them.
author: Jarinya P.

description:
Highlights
- Sheng Kee is my go to spot when I need to grab some last minute beautifully presented pastries, bread, and cake. 
- Pineapple buns: Soft, fluffy, and slightly sweet top  (not the crumbly layer that falls all over the place on top of the bun like some other bakeries). 
- Taiwan toast: Thick, carb loaded, bread slices. My favorite to eat plain or with jam!
- Hot dog buns: You would never think to get hot dog buns at a Chinese bakery, but it's really not bad from here. 
- Vanilla cake with fruit filling is the best choice, skip the mousse cakes. You can count on them to not make it overly sweet and the cream is like a whipped cream. 
- There is seating and tables here as well as drink offerings. 

Improvements
- Pastry items don't look to fresh at this location compared to what I've gotten in the South Bay locations and some are on the verge of being burnt or on the dry side. Maybe it's because they don't individually package each bun in plastic bags, but it does save the environment!
- If you decide to get a chocolate cake, don't count on it being rich and chocolatey like American chocolate cakes. Think hint of chocolate like cocoa powdered cake instead. 

Tip
- Parking is difficult here, take public transit or good luck finding metered or street parking nearby.
author: Tracy T.

description: Some of the baked goods are hit or miss. When you arrive to pick up food at 7AM when they've just opened, things are just coming out of the oven and they may not have what you are looking for.  There are 3 items I like to buy from Sheng Kee Bakery (chain) - their egg tarts are not as good as the ones you can find in Chinatown (Napolean Bakery or Golden Gate Bakery) and cost more, their Portuguese egg tarts are better - less sugar and the tops are caramelized, and their coconut buns are good. I really like their chicken pot pies.  They're a pastry puff shell filled with thickened gravy with chunks of chicken (some days more chicken than others), a little too salty but satisfying. Not to be mistaken for the frozen Banquet, Marie Callender's or Swanson chicken pot pies you buy in the supermarket.  Staff is always pleasant here.
author: Ry T.

description:
Stumbled upon this place looking for a quick snack, glad I went in. Very clean and very cheap bakery. Staff is polite and nice, welcoming. The food is delicious, you get way more than you pay for.
If you have some loose change in pocket and want a quick bite this place is great for you. If this was near my school when I was younger hands down they see me every day.
author: Drake G.

description: Gross. Bought one of their cakes and found strands (not one) but several strands of hair insides their cake, and I meant they were actually baked into the cake so I know it wasn't hair that fell while cake was being cut by one of my family members.  If I can, they get no star.  Aren't their bakers required to wear hair net???  So pissed off, we just threw the whole cake away.  Never going to this disgusting overpriced crap hole again.
author: Susan K.

description:
I love my pasteries.  Ran in here on my way to the SF Zine Fest at Golden Gate park.  Great way to save money if you don't want to pay tons of money for a meal.  I picked up some great treats to share with my friends.  Taro bun, Taro Pineapple Bun, chocolate bun and 3 Portuguese custards, and a honey green tea w/boba.  All were really good.  

My favorites were the boba tea, so cheap!  Tons of boba which is my favorite to chew on.  What else???  Oh the Portuguese custards, they were warm and full of flavor.
author: Michelle M.

description: I got a crispy fish sandwich and a blueberry bun..for like $4.35. It was really good.
author: Denise C.

description:
I've been to other Sheng Kee locations before and this one just didn't live up to my expectations. However, I did freestyle my order and went with s Beef Curry Bun and a Bacon Bun, about $1.60 each, instead of going with the Yelp Highlighted items. 

Beef Curry Bun: It was like a BBQ pork bun except with curry beef inside. Not great flavor and thought there should be more savoriness to it.

Bacon Bun: Open faced with BBQ sauce, soft bacon, and cheese baked on top. I expected it to not taste like a bunch of grease for some reason. Aside from that, the flavor was okay.

One star for price and one star for service. I'll come back and try and egg tart or milk tea sometime but this was a 2 star experience in my book.
author: Chris W.

description: A nice cozy bakery, with some serine area. They have plenty of options, and the service is good.
author: Ernesto S.

description:
I work in the neighborhood, so I depended on this place for lunch the first few weeks. That was changed when I discovered all of their food is served cold and often has hair in it. The prices are amazing, but.. what are you paying for, exactly? 

Their sponge rolls are the best and that's about it. The rest is cold and hairy.
author: Cecilia A.

description: I was here with a stroller during the weekday. They have tasty buns and didn't kick me out when I wanted to sit for a while. The prices are reasonable and the onion buns were really tasty. They have cakes too but I didn't try those.
author: Sofya T.

description:
I came here twice about a year ago and really liked it - cheap and interesting savory and sweet pastries, those egg custard tarts, and bubble tea. What wasn't to like?

Here's what happened today that made me change my mind about this place:

1) No more egg custard tarts. Best thing they made, and they no longer carry it. What gives?

2) The basil, tomato pastries tasted like mold. I got two b/c they're super tasty WHEN NOT MOLDY, but both had  a moldy taste. My sis had to spit hers out in a trash can and wash out her mouth it was so bad. I should've taken 'em back, but I was too far away. Couldn't tell from looking at it, but it tasted terrible.

3) Tiger Milk Tea - WAAY too sweet. I'm a big fan of sweet, and I could hardly drink the stuff. The boba was pretty good, though

4) The bathroom is in the way back, and so I don't think you used to need a key, which was great to have a bathroom at a place. but the bathroom needs a key, so I walked all the way down there, dropped my stuff and got ready, and then it was locked. So I had to go back and get the key. Total hassle. They need a sign up front letting you know what's up.

So, they messed up a good thing is all I have to say. Why mess with a good thing?
author: Ari F.

description: I come here for the tea! $2 milk tea (boba included) that is actually not powder cannot be beat!
author: Marissa P.

description: Unless I'm mistaken... not one of the reviews here mentions their chocolate chip walnut cookie. But it's HONESTLY the best cookie I've ever had. Packed with chopped roasted walnuts and semi-sweet chocolate morsels. Chewy and moist and just wonderful!!!!! PLZ TRY IT. It's only $1.50!
author: Gloria P.

description:
Love their mango mousse cake! I have ordered it a few times for friends' birthdays and everyone always loves it. They'll write any message you want on a piece of white chocolate as long as you tell them in advance. I've literally ordered a cake for my friends birthday just three hours before picking it up and they made it happen! Talk about convenience. 

I've never had anything else here besides the mango mousse, but I highly recommend it. It's really light and favorable.
author: Anastasia N.

description:
Totally wannabe 85*c (SoCal chain). The other Sheng Kee locations I have frequented are not quite set up the same one. Each bao is individually wrapped and you just put it on a tray and get rung up.

Here, each pastry isn't wrapped. You walk in, grab a tray that is lined with wax paper, a set of tongs, and browse. While you browse, use the tongs to pick and choose. They'll either wrap your pastry up or put it in a paper bag for you at the counter when they ring you up. 

They offer Peet's coffee and other various HK-ish desserts/drinks.

Just a standard Sheng Kee, nothing special.. Either the prices have gone up or this location is just a little more pricey because it's on the end of Irving.
author: Susy C.

description: They setup new rules. Poor service especially  that cashier girl gave me a hard time.
author: Joina C.

description: Sheng Kee has such cute decorative cakes and their pastries are wonderful - lots of buns, mini cakes, yum!  They serve Peet's coffee and nice friendly service.  We will remember this place for sure when we are in the neighborhood!
author: Maile N.

description: I came here with a friend for breakfast one weekday. As someone who doesn't normally eat the average "breakfast" foods, I was intrigued by all of the savory options they had in addition to the sweet selections. I got one of the hot dog buns and one of the ham and cheese rolls. Both were fresh out of the oven and tasted great. The low prices made it even better. It was nice to sit at the tables and eat versus take it for the road. Overall I would come back to try out the many options available.
author: Matt P.

description:
(See pics) Review #1290. I love all the very beautifully presented and delicious choices of cakes, swiss rolls as well as all the Chinese pastries and buns here. The bonus part is you can sit around (some tables at front and also at the back) and enjoy all the Italian coffee drinks and goodies while letting the sunset comes and the fog rolls in.

This is a bakery that is like a candy store, filled with all the bright colors settings and all the very aromatic and delicious baked pastries, bread, tarts. You will be taking deep breaths, enjoying each piece and have a cup of specialty coffee (think white mocha.)

They also had different kinds of celebration cakes, whether it's birthdays, anniversaries, or just because, you will find those with fresh fruits, chestnut paste, not sugary sweet and happily light whipped cream.
author: T L.

description:
I was too early for an event so I decided to walk along Irving and have something to eat. The pastries here looked wonderful.  It was a hard decision, but I finally decided on a small square of green tea mouse cake.  I enjoyed it, and it was a real bargain at $1.99.  

There were several other goodies I wanted buy. I didn't want to carry them in the "no food or drink" show I was going to go to. So, I planned to return for an order to go after browsing at the Vintage Paper Show. 

I quickly changed my mind.  I did not like walking past the disgusting mess that the homeless had made on the street, but I was going to anyway. I figured I could walk off the sidewalk to avoid the stuff. However, the pastries were not good enough for me to listen to verbal insults from 3 panhandlers on a half block walk
author: Terry T.

description: Perfect place for birthday cakes that aren't overly sweet.  We've gotten the green tea cake on multiple occasions (especially for my parents' birthdays) and each time it's been consistently good quality.
author: Robert L.

description:
This is my favorite bakery to feed my taro addiction. And I went on a hunt to find taro pastries, from Chinatown to Richmond. =.=

Here, the taro items are as follow:

Purple romance bun
Taro mochi pastry
Taro filled pineapple bun. 
Taro swirled brick toast.  
Taro red bean cake. 

My two cents: The least sweet is the purple romance bun, and the taro mochi is like a small version of the purple romance bun. The sweetest is the taro filled pineapple bun, where the buttery pineapple crust is the best part. My favorite is the cake because it has a rich and dense taro filling. 

Also, this place has the best brick toast bread. Their plain toast is great. So, is their dried pork, custard, and taro toasts! This is the only bread that I will buy myself and eat freely without worrying about empty calories. 

Lastly, I like this place much more than 85C in SoCal. Sheng Kee has a more Taiwanese feel to it because 85C serves more Americanized items like danishes.
author: Mabel Y.

description: If you like chinese pastries, bread, buns, and cakes it's a easy buy. Almost everything is prepackaged! This is my childhood bakery, try the sponge rolls!
author: Fiona Y.

description:
This is a pretty fun bakery. The employees here are super nice.  The Asian pastries are all reasonably priced and the selection is pretty amazing. They offer Peets coffee and its made well. I do like the coconut buns and have ventured into some things that I have never seen. The taro buns are great, the green onion buns are awesome. Sometimes there is a bit of a language barrier but everybody that I have dealt with has been really nice.
   If you are feeling adventurous and want to try something besides a donut or bagel hit this place up. 
  Dont be Gluten intolerant, love gluten, because it plentiful here.
author: Atom H.

description:
Man, was this place disappointing. Sheng Kee was my mom's favorite bakery in Taiwan. She grew up on it and went to it all the time while she was at National Taiwan University. So when she told me to check out the SF location (this was the first of the two I visited), I had high expectations. 

Well, color me disappointed.

The selection was abysmal. Maybe it just happened to be a bad night. But I came here twice in one week and both times, I was unimpressed by the pastries on tap (yeah, I just coined that phrase). None of them were particularly Taiwanese and seemed to be designed to cater to American/Western palates (e.g. utilizing un-Asian ingredients like cream cheese). 

I got a package of pineapple cakes (absolutely THE item to try in a Taiwanese bakery--it's pretty much the thing you judge the bakery on) and an entire cheesecake. The cakes were fantastic: the pastry shell was firm yet soft, crumbly and buttery, and the paste had the perfect amount of fresh pineapple and sugar. The cheesecake was not very good--too spongey, too much like Japanese cheesecake (which is a whole other texture).

Service wasn't bad. The guy behind the counter was really friendly and had that teasing/joking rapport with all the customers. Seating isn't abundant, so this might not be the place to linger in during busy times. The other location has far more tables.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Yay for Sheng Kee!

I came here the other day to buy a birthday cake for a friend. We got the raspberry mango mouse cake and it was DELICIOUS! They also offer to write something on the cake as well. So if you have a friend who doesn't want a cake that's too carb-like and they like the texture of mouse, I would recommend it!

Sheng Kee also has lots of Chinese baked goods. Everything looks very tasty and delicious. I don't usually buy anything because I don't know what to get. The moon cake I saw did look cute, small and reasonably priced. I have tried the mocha bread in the fridge area and I like that a lot, I think it's worth it.

This Sheng Kee location also has chairs for people to sit and eat.
author: Margaret L.

description:
This location is pretty cool. Kind of hidden. The store front isn't as wide as the other store locations. 
This location won me with so many sandwich options and they were all less than $3. Maybe it's because i came in at lunch time instead of the usual weekend late afternoon hour at the other irving location. 
I did take away 1 star bc it seemed they lacked in the pastry bun variety selection compared to other location.
author: Christi S.

description:
A really amazing place to get asian pastries! I typically get the pineapple bun along with a Hong Kong milk tea and it is the perfect breakfast combination. 

The place is very clean and has a wide selection of pastries from red bean buns, bbq buns to more western style pastries like hot dog cheese buns. I appreciate the fact they note when the pastries were made so you can pick the freshest ones.
author: Karen H.

description: They don't have too much of a selection of breads. Something that annoyed me a bit was that they don't align their labels to the corresponding bread. This is something basic that all bakeries do. It wouldn't be a problem but this Sheng Kee puts three different types of bread into a single compartment for some breads. I assumed that their labels align correctly with the breads displayed, and I ended up buying a croissant type bread when I actually wanted to buy a green tea bread. The croissant almond danish that I ended up buying was too dry and didn't taste flaky at all.
author: Theresa L.

description:
I'm from Cupertino, so you'll have to forgive my 2 star rating. 

The breads here are very small, and the prices are definitely too high. 
For asian breads, one with like green onions and hot dogs are generally a dollar. Here, it goes for 1.85.... for a smaller version.

This goes for most of the breads here. I won't be back. I'd rather grab it from Cupertino when I'm back at home, and then drive it up. Or maybe check out a near by Chinatown. 

Not recommended. Won't come back. I've definitely experienced better.
author: Kaje Y.

description:
I bought two of the custard tarts, a custard filled bun, and a chocolate filled/chocolate drizzled thing....

I wouldn't know how good they were because my bf and sister ate them all. 
So I would have to say they were good based on how fast they disappeared.
author: Mandi W.

description:
The inside of this Sheng Kee is just as Chinese as any other Sheng Kee ... except there are no Chinese labels. Kinda makes it hard for people who are used to the Chinese names for the buns. They have everything all the other Sheng Kee Bakeries have, and possibly more. You think that they'd raise the prices because it's in a "White" neighborhood, but they're actually about the same.

Anyway, you have to get their honey toast! (See pictures) It has to be special ordered at the counter and you have to eat it there while it's still hot. You won't regret!

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
The newest Sheng Kee has plenty of baked Chinese buns, cakes, cookies, and pastries (mooncakes, danish, croissants, egg custard tarts) to choose from (grab a tray and tongs first), including some varieties I haven't seen at their other locations. The refrigerated case has sandwiches, pudding, pannacotta, cake rolls and drinks. Baked buns include hot dog, pizza, taro, red bean, pork sung, custard, etc. New items include French bacon sandwiches, red bean/taro pannacotta, and Danish sandwiches.

* Tuna bun: looks like a hot dog bun, exterior bun pretty dry and bland, should be softer, interior filled with canned tuna salad, not too much mayo, decent 
* Ham & cheese Danish sandwich ($1.99): a small square sandwich, flaky butter Danish with a thin layer of ham and cheese, mixed greens, pretty dry, could use more mayo or mustard mixed greens
* Red bean bun ($1.19): Dough is different than the typical Sheng Kee, it's harder, bun is flatter and less full of air, dry dense dough, good amount of filling, chunky red bean lots of bean flavor, some of the beans are really hard, almost crunchy

So far the items look better than they taste and they're not as good as the average Sheng Kee.
author: Lolia S.

description:
I am so glad this place isn't closer to me, or I'd gain so much weight.

Solid selection of baked goods both savory and sweet at reasonable prices. My favorites are the taro-based ones. The one issue with my visit there was that the pineapple buns were mislabeled. I went home and was about to enjoy my pineapple bun when I bit into what was actually a bbq pork bun. Just. not. the. same.
author: Rowena L.

description:
Anybody ever been to 85 degrees down south? It is so yummy. AZN bakery goodness.  This place is similar just not as orgasmic.  Props to being open late. Props for being dirt cheap. 

Do yourself a favor and get the sugared and buttered toast, it will surely sugar and butter your vagina as it did mine.
author: Chelsey G.

description:
Great build. Epic drop.

The build:

- Sweet pineapple bun
- Sweeter cranberry infused wheat bun
- Delectable strawberry sponge cake
- Intense red bean bun
- Beautiful looking and beautiful tasting mango mousse

The drop:

- Unique and brilliant green tea mousse

Sorry to see the previous tenant Beautifull go. Happy to see the inexpensive yet full of flavor Sheng Kee arrive.

Come for the build. Stay for the drop. 

Few more epic drops: https://open.spotify.com/user/jbshark/playlist/3rAIBOG2LofthPpi2bwvSY

(thanks for the inspiration Akshay)
author: Jason B.

description:
I'm so glad that there's a Sheng Kee Bakery nearby now.  I mean, I guess walking a mile or so wouldn't hurt, considering all the delicious baked goods I buy/eat each time.  But it's nice to have one so close to home.  

I visited this new location around 2:30 p.m. on a Friday afternoon.  The place had a couple other customers at the time.  There was plenty of selection: savory and sweets.  Sandwiches, hot dog buns, shredded pork buns, flan, custard tarts, pineapple buns, taro buns.  They have a nice selection of cakes and fancier desserts inside the case as well.  You just grab a tray and a pair of tongs and choose your pastries.  I got:

-Chocolate moon shaped bread ($1.45): very fresh and the sprinkles were actually chocolate (they melt!), not just hard and plain.  The bun has a nice crust to it and is buttery.  The bread is filled with a couple blobs of chocolate- the whole thing is really good if toasted (or microwaved) for a little bit.

-Portuguese custard tart ($1.35): It's very sweet and very eggy-custardy.  I enjoyed it very much.  The "crust" was very flakey and buttery and the whole thing was delicious.  

Overall the pricing is fair and the product is yummy.  They have tables in front/outside of the shop as well as in the back too if you want to enjoy your pastries there.  The man helping me at the counter seemed a little bit out of it, he didn't know the prices/names of the items I got- but I'll assume that he's just training still.  I'll be back, and maybe next time, this will be bumped up to a four.
author: Samantha L.

description:
The aroma of baked goodness spreads up and down Irving street.  I came to eat at Perilla a few doors down, but couldn't wait to finish and grab some pastries from Sheng Kee afterwards.  

This bakery is extremely clean.  Maybe it's because they opened recently, but I couldn't get over how shiny and new everything looked.  It made me want to buy one of everything.  From pork buns to cake, there has to be about 3 dozen different kinds of baked goodies they sell here.

After making my rounds, I decided on an almond croissant, custard bun, custard tart, and an onion bun.  All of my choices were delicious.  The croissant was nice a flaky with not too much almond paste.  I had my eyes on the chocolate croissant and pineapple bun as well, so I'll have to come back and try those also.  Everything here is probably only about $1-2 per item.
author: Anthony N.

description:
Conveniently located less than a block from the N train, this is a great place to pickup birthday cakes and pastries. I really like their bubble tea too! Their boba is always fresh and chewy, and their teas are not too sweet. 
I love their cakes, its so light and fluffy, without being overwhelmingly sweet.
author: Nancy Z.

description: This review is just for the boba tea. I got the almond milk tea and it was crazy sweet.
