My husband got the plain milk tea and it was good but we both thought the boba themselves were really big and bland. I wouldn't come back for tea again. The staff seemed really nice and helpful though :)
author: Rachael T.

description:
My wife got a rolled up cake that she liked. We double parked and may have gotten a ticket. Will find out soon if it was a very expensive cake. 

DW tried to find out if their taro bun was made with soy as I'm very allergic. First guy said no that it had vegetable oil. She asked someone else who said yes - soy oil. No taro bun for me.
author: Marco M.

description:
Nice! There are Sheng Kee Bakeries all over the Bay Area and so when they opened up a new one on Irving we had to check it out.

This location is huge, has a sit down area and the baked goods are really fresh.

I got my favorite "crispy pork bun" (it's basically shredded pork inside a a Chinese croissant crust) and it was delicious.

I would definitely come back to this location!
author: Betty C.

description: Sheng Kee Bakery is an awesome little pastry shop in the Inner Sunset neighborhood. My friend and I came here for a small snack and they had a wide variety of items to choose from. I had myself a hot dog and cheese bun and I thought it was excellent, and at $1.19 a great value, too. My friend had a ham and mushroom bun and she seemed to enjoy her pastry as well. The service was quick and friendly and the interior was clean and well lit. Many seats and tables are available in the back for customers who choose to stay and enjoy their food. The music was quite loud when we were there so it was not the best environment for conversation. Bonus points for having a restroom for customers and for being open until 10pm. I look forward to trying more of their products whenever I am in the area. Mahalo to my friend for introducing me to Sheng Kee Bakery!
author: Kevin Y.

description: Can't go wrong with the $3.50 bubble tea & fried chicken sandwich special!!
author: Alice Z.

description: I had their Portuguese egg custard $1.35/each and some German cup/cake thing. I wouldn't suggest to order these. The Portuguese custard was like a blob of mush in your mouth. The crust was flaky. Save your $1.35 and get yourself a delicious tart from the famous Chinatown.
author: Jess W.

description:
A new Sheng Kee that's so convenient for me! It has been my new go to place, it was previously Arizmendi. (Don't worry Arizmendi, I still love you). 

Sheng Kee has decent price pastries topped with yummy goodness. I like the mushroom, cheese, and ham bread. The dangerous cheesy pineapple, corn, and ham danish isn't bad either. The first time I had it was great, the second time however, the corn tasted a bit stale. I'm not too big of a fan of their buns with green onions and hot dogs. The hot dogs were way too salty. However, for a small tuna sandwich for less than $2, you can't really beat that. 

I've always enjoyed it to go, but I hope to one day take advantage of the back patio they have.
author: Mandy D.

description: I return to my old neighborhood and was surprised at the Sheng Kee Bakery on 9th/Irving.  I remember the selection of pastries--both sweets and savories---that they usually carry.  The stuff I got was underwhelming.
author: Grace M.

description: This place reminds me of a place in Irvine called 85 degree bakery but much smaller. Last night, we were able to find parking right in front. Unfortunately they had run out of boba, but that was just because they were closing. Otherwise, their pastries were pretty good. I got an almond pastry, which was pretty great =) my bf got a blueberry filled donut & that was pretty good too! They have pretty cheap pastries & they're boba is also reasonably priced ($1.99)-- the price includes boba. I've been here before & I enjoyed their pastries. I'll definitely be back.
author: Brittany D.

description: I love their sandwiches.  Cheap and delicious food.  People are always helpful and friendly.
author: Nanz L.

description:
This Sheng Kee location blends in well with its part of the neighborhood. It's not on the Chinesefied part of Irving (past 19th Ave), and thus can get away with a difference in quality, that is good enough to appeal to non Chinese clientele who might not be able to tell what a good authentic Hong Kong style pineapple bun should taste like, or care that the pork floss bun looks more lke a chia pet on a bun, but will gladly eat a hot dog cheese bun and think it's the best thing in the world.

The Macau/Portguese style egg tart did look slightly better than the kind from the San Mateo branch, but structural integrity was quite poor as the egg custard made the bottom part of the crust so moist that it crumbled on the tin it rested on (and thus made the experience less interesting), and thus leaving one's fingers deep in greaseville trying to put it in one's mouth. At virtually $1.35 per, not a cheap endeavor (especially a messy and not so great one)....have to give the tip of the hat to Sogo Bakery (Burlingame) for their even better and more refined rendition. Given the lackluster execution, not holding up hopes for the regular Cantonese style egg tarts (which makes me wonder where Hongry Kong Truck got their receipe).

Not a huge fan otherwise of this branch's Sheng Kee offerings, even based on visual inspection of the remaining selection. The pineapple buns don't look right (they need to be big round at the very least, and BOLD....Kee Wah makes a definitive version with a secret crispy texture). The "Taiwanese" side of things don't seem very Taiwanese at all (look at Sogo Burlingame, or 85 C in Irvine, or JJ's in Arcadia, Irvine  for their versatility etc). So the conclusion is that it's an ok Asian bakery, but not Hong Kong or Taiwanese enough in terms of standards.

As much as I enjoy the decor (it's generally better looking than most other Sheng Kee locations) and appreciate the fact that they sell tapioca milk tea like drinks in attempt to be different from the others (although very likely executed to a standard nowhere close to my liking), perhaps investing more into bread and pastry and bun quality, and making/baking techniques...stealing ideas from Japanese bakeries yet adding a classic European twist, would easily make this location a much superior branch than others. Kudos for serving Illy coffee.
author: Ken K.

description: Japan Red Bean Cream Cheese Bun - do it!
author: Colleen M.

description: Came to this location because I didn't want to deal with the traffic mess surrounding their 20th avenue location, bad choice on my part. The pastries at this location look like they've been sitting for a while...probably because they don't get as much turnaround as they do by 19th avenue...in addition, their cakes did not look very appetizing...the Japanese cheesecake was literally peeling apart. It was my first choice cake, but after seeing its decrepit condition, I ended up settling on a basic fruit cake instead. Though very moist, it ought to be renamed whipped cream and fruit cake. The sheer amount of cream on this cake is ridiculous! Cream all over the outside, between each layer, and also within the fruit cocktail. On the plus side, it looked pretty...my grandmother validated that.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Things to be prepare for when checking out:

1. Not the friendliest folks. They sometimes rush customers when they're checking out... you should prepare your payment ahead of time.

2. If you look Asian, they're probably gonna tell you your total in Chinese. But that's okay. You can pretend you understand them because the price shows up on the register screen thing.

I prefer the Inner Sunset location. It's cleaner and friendlier. But I like this location too-- I go here more often because it's closer to where I live and it's also conveniently located near grocery stores, banks, boba cafes, whatever u want. 

You can get in and out pretty fast and no one is rushing you when you are picking your baked goods, though it can get kind of squishy if it's busy.. but people usually don't take that long to decide what they want! I mean... if you're having problems deciding which piece of goodie you want... well, one word: YOLO. :)

But for real, their goods outweigh their service by a whole lot so I don't mind the minor "unfriendly" checkout situations.
author: Yer L.

description:
I just want to write a review for constructive criticism, and to warn people. I saw two separate incidences so it really bothered me.

I am a Nurse and have worked in the food industry before, clean hands, and uniforms are a MUST. You pick something off the floor, go wash your hands, you can't just put on a glove and call it a day....

1.) walking by one day, the man whom is wearing the Bakers apron, sitting out side, dug a finger into his nose and wiped it on his apron. I get it this sounds unreal but I wouldn't just say it. That is NOT ok. I could only hope after his break he put a new apron on. 

2.) the woman that took my credit card at the cashier had her gloves on as she took money and cards. When she walked away from the cashier there was no hand washing involved. She had the same gloves on after handling my card and money then went over to go make a drink.  I just walked out. I cannot trust a place that does not put effort into cleanliness. Touching money is DIRTY. Not washing your hands after handling dirty money and before you handle food is NOT OK!!! I don't want to think about what might be happening in the back where customers can't see.

Take what you want from the review, I think it is the general publics right to be aware of poor hygiene in a Bakery. I'll walk half a block to a trusted clean Bakery.
author: Natalie J.

description: Great quality.  Reasonable price.  Many fresh items to choose.  Now this is my favorate bakery in sf.
author: Sam A.

description: I LOVE THIS BAKERY. My boyfriend takes me here for coconut buns, he gets chocolate pastries, and they are all AMAZING. They have a great selection and the staff is always nice. The coffee is so-so and they only have whole milk but it's not really a coffee place I guess. My favorite!
author: Brianna C.

description:
Very cheap bakery in my hood. Pastries taste OK. What upsets me is that they serve Peet's coffee and don't know anything about it. Right after ordering an americano at the counter, I found out that the cashier lady rang me up for a caramel latte (which is way more expensive) due to lack of her English. I didn't want a caramel latte, so asked a barista girl to make me americano, cause that what I wanted. She stared at me confused. She didn't know what americano was. I explained her that she simply needs to add water to an espresso shot. She still were looking confused. Finally said, 'What do you want?" I had to have her very foamy latte instead.
So nice for baked goodies, no more coffee there!
author: Rom M.

description:
sheng kee here is smaller than the big one up the street. not much of a line. less selection. (looking at the displays, not by actual count)

eats: custard tart(1)
-not like typical cantonese ones that tastes watered down.
-solid custard filling but not much taste
-nice crust.

crumbs:
-maybe i should have splurged and went portuguese.
author: Victor G.

description:
I know everyone likes the other Sheng Kee near 19th Avenue, but the evening pastry options are more plentiful here than the other bakery. All of the the savory breads were available, and the purple taro puffs were beautifully done. I bought myself the coconut sweet bread...it was good and not too sweet. 

They have tables and chairs to sit, but no bathrooms. Service was brisk. A nice night snacks place for those who love carbs!
author: Pauline L.

description:
I may be a little biased, because Asian breads are one of my favorite indulgences, but I loved everything I've tried here! We stumbled upon this bakery before heading to the de Young, and couldn't pass up the opportunity to get some pineapple cakes and taro bread. 

We got a red bean pastry, a mocha mousse, and an almond bread, all delicious. 

We were in the area the next night, getting dinner at Marnee Thai - also 5 stars for having the best angel wings I have ever had - so went back for more, and got taro bread, green tea cake, and more pineapple cakes!

Moral of the story: If you are even in the area, get dinner at Marnee Thai, followed by dessert here!
author: Jane S.

description:
It's just a smaller version of the bigger store on 20-somethingth. 

It's not amazing or anything, although it's nice to have an Asian Bakery so close to 9th. Definitely easier to grab stuff and jump back on the N to either get to the boyfriends or back to my own place. The stuff is about the same as the bigger place. The pineapple bun is just as good as ever. I tried this taro purple panna cotta stuff and it was pretty good. It was a little confusing since they had their doors closed and had all their staff cleaning up when I went at about 9pm so we thought they were closed.
author: Nina Y.

description: I have always loved this bakery since it is a chain and they have them all over the place. I went here the other day to pick up a mocha sponge cake and a ham and cheese pastry. The ham and cheese pastry was delicious and when I went back today after school of course it was all sold out =(. I have yet to try the mocha sponge cake was good as usual. When I went back today I ended up getting the coconut bread which is my all time favorite and it never disappoints, I am glad this bakery is only in SF otherwise I would be super fat all the time.
author: Abigail L.

description: Walked in here because it looked so pretty from the outside but they didnt have a sign outside. I looked at the cakes and said, "hey..this looks like sheng kee cakes" they were! this establishment def is more bright and modern. Which suckered us into buying a few baos that were about to go on sale. They are only opened for a week, there are free samples, and lots of seating! :]
author: kim w.

description:
I stopped in here after dinner (bonus points for being open late!) to grab some dessert and something to have for breakfast tomorrow.  I was really impressed by the variety of items and how reasonable the prices are.  

After much deliberation, we left with a custard bun, German Custard Tart, and a ham and corn bun.  I can't speak to the ham and corn yet, but based on the custard and tart, I know I'll be taking many guilty walks to this place--adios New Years Resolutions!
author: Danny G.

description:
The bacon bun. Amazing. 
Also, they have a $5 minimum for credit card purchases, so make sure you buy more than one bacon bun. :)
author: Hannah P.

description:
This Sheng Kee locations has friendly staff on the night shift. It's open late compared to the other locations. 

For a bit of background, Sheng Kee is a chain of Hong Kong style bakeries around the Bay Area. Although I think a portion of their baked goods are trucked in, I like the place and more importantly their HK style milk tea. I've been able to get HK style milk tea as late at 8:30 here unlike other locations that can run out before they close. 

If you are first timer to such a bakery, you'll need to grab a tray and a set of tongs to pile any pastries from the shelves for purchase. I love many of the garlic items, but sometimes the texture can be either stiff or slightly tough. Unsure if it's suppose to be that way, but I'd argue to let your taste buds decide if you like it or not. The chicken curry pot pie is quite an easy item for beginners to HK bakeries.

Street parking can be rather tight. If you are coming by car and having a hard time, go to their other location on Irving between 21st and 20th.
author: Paul F.

description:
Is it me or is this Sheng Kee exceptionally better than their other stores? I've been to many Sheng Kees and this is the only one in which I wanted one of EVERYTHING. This particular store has offerings that I've never seen before at other Sheng Kees and they all looked amazingly fresh and delicious. I noticed more "westernized" items here such as danishes and sandwiches as opposed to the usual cake rolls and baos. The whole cakes in the glass case didn't look very fresh though. 

Today, we got:
- Almond Danish Toast: basically a croissant in a mini-loaf form! So cute and yummy.
- Chicken Pie and Hot Dog & Onion Bun: didn't try but the bf loved em.
All for $5!

Def wanna come back to try their thick toast and different varieties of baked flan :)
author: Helen L.

description:
I might be wrong, but I read some reviews saying how Sheng Kee is the original 85c.  But from what I remember, Sheng Kee didn't have these types of baked good nor this type of system until after 85c became popular.  But I might be wrong.

Now onto the store.  I came on a Saturday afternoon and it was averagely empty.  The baked good are okay.  85c is still pwnage compared to this place but it suffices.  They have a LOT of the same things you would see at 85c such as Taro Bun, a copy of the Very Berry from 85c, and the typical asian baked goods (hot dog bun, pork bun, brick toast, etc).

The price is average, not cheap nor expensive.  Would come again if I was in the area and wanted some asian baked goods.
author: Willis C.

description:
So far the first item that I bought here is also the first reason to go here:
CURRIED BEEF DONUTS
Really...
author: Antoinette S.

description: The selection isn't as good as the ones in Berkeley or El Cerrito, however there is still as good customer service compared to the other two. The one thing I wish the other stores would adopt though is the tart warmer on the front counter! Having still warm dantaat with that flaky crust after a breezy day in East BAy would improve my experience a lot D:
author: Raven P.

description:
I decided to try this new bakery. I can't say this is a fair review because I don't think I like Chinese pastries after this experience. 

I had a hotdog in a bun, a custard and some mocha chocolate mousse. After two bites, I left the hot dog on the street for a homeless person. 

The custard was delicious with a flakey crust and lovely middle. 

The mousse tasted like an ok tiramisu. It wasn't bad but it wasn't great and I didn't eat the white cake in it because that tasted bad. Why are they calling it mousse if it has cake in it??  I like Tart to Tart's mousses.

Of course you can't beat $1.89 for a tuna sandwich but I'm not gonna buy it. I would like to try the blueberry flan but that's about it.
author: Lisa C.

description:
I went to Sheng Kee on Irving at 9th Ave this afternoon and I tried one of the many pastries that is offered. I wanted to try Sheng Kee's version of an almond croissant. It is very delicious and rivals the one made by La Boulange. Local chef and caterer Ramni Levy was also visiting the new location and he was eager to find something to sample from the varied array of pastries and food items. 

It was not easy because there is so much to select from. Sheng Kee offers both sweet pastries as well as savory ones. Pizza-like creations and mini pies and very enticing cakes and breads. All in many shapes sizes and filled with all types of flavors, etc. 

Chef Levy had the raisin roll. He was kind to share some of it with me for this review. The raisin roll is similar to a cinnamon roll only it is all about raisins. And, like the almond croissant it is delicious. 

I am eager to go back at another time and try something savory, like one of the lunch sandwiches or maybe one of the meat pies. 

Coffee is pretty good. I will have to go back and try a cafe latte or something because they serve Illy brand Italian coffee.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
Had their dried shredded pork bun w/ green onion. It was a quick spot to stop in, grab a snack. If I lived in this area, I could see myself coming in, getting enough pastries to give me a delightful treat to reheat in the AMs for breakfast.

It's a fair price, 1.50 ish a bun. Generally fresh. Fair service.
author: Danny N.

description:
Do yourself a favor and try the green tea mochi puff pastry. SO GOOD. The first time I ever got it i kinda just put it on the tray cause I like green tea flavored anything but I totally forgot about it until I reached in the bag later.  When I took a bite, the mochi threw me off guard but then I realized it was... SO GOOD. 
Now whenever I'm in the inner sunset I make sure to stop by and pick up at least 2  cause I know just one wont satisfy my needs! haha
The only downside is that each one costs about $1.85 and coming from socal where asian bakeries are everywhere, i'm not really used to paying closer to a dollar for each pastry. Whatever though. I'm still gonna keep buying them!
author: Ariel C.

description:
After having dinner at Patxi's, I was drawn into Sheng Kee Bakery by the overwhelming buttery smell wafting from inside. 

I bought an assortment of things that I thought looked delicious and they were, in fact, very delicious. I've had some stuff from Sheng Kee before and I've had this opinion that their stuff was dry and tasteless. However, this time, I've changed my mind and I think it's delicious. I was also excited to find out that this particular location is new only to find out that I have one closer to me that's only a couple of blocks away. haha.

Anyway, they have delicious stuff. And it's pretty inexpensive too!
author: Rylan C.

description:
Thanks for updating the info on this, Yelp. :)

Btw, i've been back a few times after the first review and may I add their HK style milk tea is fantastic?  Yes...yes I may.  The folks here are also really nice...I hope they keep this up after the honeymoon period.
author: Sally T.

description: Great pastries and pretty decent coffee selection (Illy coffee!) I actually sat down and this place is clean and well maintained.  I think they're trying to attract a younger crowd because the music was blasting and the bright neon colored decor was energizing not calming. The seating is actually quite long and narrow towards the back and they also offer a few bistro seats in the front for people watching.  I was pleasantly surprised with the tomato danish- made with croissant pastry, crispy and slightly sweet. The selection of pastries is quite impressive and it seems like they have a fairly decent turnover. Service here has always been speedy.
author: Naomi K.

description: Pricey for a Chinese bakery. Each char siu bao was $1.60 each. I would have love to try different baked goods, but spending more than $10 on bakery stuff just doesn't seem right!
author: Jeanne C.

description: The pastries are yummy and they are super friendly. They answered all my questions about the unique pastries and while sitting out front eating the manager brought me a sea salt cappuccino. Sounds strange but I was surprised it was good :)
author: Missy M.

description:
I came here for ONE, and ONE thing only. Their Custard Bun.
One word to describe it: DISAPPOINTING.

So I'm a HUGE fan of 85C Bakery in socal. (No I'm not from there so I'm not biased) What I love from 85C is their MILK PUDDING BUN. 
So, you can imagine my delight when the bf says to me that Sheng Kee has a Custard Bun, which he assumed was comparable.
IT'S NOT. Don't let the swirl of custard fool you. They look similar, but completely different. 
One, Sheng Kee's custard is somewhat hard and solid, nothing like the pudding texture of 85C milk pudding bun.
Two, Sheng Kee's bread LOOKS soft and delicious, but looks can be deceiving. It's not as soft as it looks, and taste was just bland. They don't seem to stay soft and fresh as long as 85C breads either.

I bought 3, one to snack on later that day and 2 for the following days as breakfast. After the first one, I left the last two with the bf. Didn't bother to bring it home.
author: Jenna H.

description:
If you've ever been to 85 degrees... you will realize that this is like a subpar, norcal version of this famous bakery (sorry, gotta throw in some socal pride! even though it's not originally from there~ lol)

Selection was smaller. It was a lot less crowded (which is more of a plus than a minus). And it just felt like an 85 degrees wannabe, with their trays and their similar plastic containers to hold the bread and the tongs that look oh so similar. (or maybe it's the other way around. I don't know... don't hate me Sheng Kee lovers!!!)

I will say that the taro jelly thing was quite delicious though :) very creamy and sweet. Pick up one of those if they happen to have it!
author: Jenni I.

description: A little bit expensive ,but it's famous bakery of Taiwan.
author: H S.

description: Liked their mousse mini cakes,  they are light, not too sweet, mousse instead of cream. They look big to fool your brain, but not dense, good for dieting!
author: Michelle R.

description: I've been to this bakery multiple times since moving into the area.  I like that it's small with modern decor.  They keep the store clean, including the bathroom (which in my experience is a rare thing for Chinese stores and restaurants).  There's free WiFi with a password for patrons.  The breads are tasty, but a little pricier than Chinese bakeries back home in Flushing, NY or even at other Chinese bakeries in the area. T hey have a variety of sweet and savory breads.  I've tried a few of the taro breads and dried pork breads, all of which were delicious!  The iced jasmine green tea with boba is good with just a hint of sweetness from the boba.  Overall, I'll be returning to this bakery often!
author: Rebecca W.

description: Best Creme Carmel in the inner Sunset! Most people come here for their baked goods and yes many traditional Chinese items they have are good but their $2 for is what we keep coming back for.
author: Alison B.

description:
I am kicking myself for having dropped my phone yesterday because now my camera app just produces a black screen, and I was thus unable to take photos of this brand new Sheng Kee for my fellow Yelpers.  Darn it!

Riding the N Judah, I noticed the brightly lit storefront and subsequently got off the train to see what the glow was all about.  With no signs outside to indicate what this beautiful new place was, I was surprised when I walked inside to find myself in a Sheng Kee.

For those who aren't familiar with Sheng Kee, it is a Chinese bakery that sells a wide variety of baked buns, pastries, and cakes.  Despite the pretty much self-service, prices here are a bit more expensive than your typical hole-in-the-wall Chinese bakery, and, honestly, I don't think the flavor quite measures up to the extra $$$.  What sets this particular location apart from other Sheng Kee locations, however, is that this one is clearly catering to a different clientele.  Stop by this Sheng Kee and then head down to the one on Irving and 20th, and you will clearly notice that they are like night and day.  The space here was spotless, there were offers of promotional and bogo pricing to entice new customers, and I was even asked whether I needed any assistance!      

Like I said, Sheng Kee isn't that special to me in general, so I won't be stopping by here often, but I do have to admit that I was impressed with the look of the place.
author: Mel T.

description: This place brings out the carb-lover in me. It's so close to home that there's little inertia to just stepping out and getting a delicious bun to have and hold. And consume. There are hits and misses though, like the time when I got a cocktail bun without any coconut cream filling inside. Devastating. And the fact that when it's early in the morning around 7:30, the place isn't well stocked and has limited selections even though it opens at 7. Sigh.. BUT.. Go try the green tea Swiss rolls in the refrigerated section, so tasty.
author: Sarah L.

description: Decent Chinese bakery with tables in the back.  As far as Chinese bakeries go, looks fancy. I don't like how the pastries are out in the open and exposed.  Makes me wary. The tomato bun was delicious and we enjoyed the green onion one too. It would be nice to have a microwave available to heat them up.  Even though the buns were good, I prefer to support independently owned mom and pop bakeries.
author: Melissa K.

description:
Man, when did this place open up? Sheng Kee is good because you know what you can expect. The pineapple buns are pretty good when they're fresh: flaky sweet crust on top of a light and airy bun. I can't confirm whether they're called pineapple buns because they look like pineapples or because they have a pineapple flavor. Pretty sure it's the first one. I'm a sucker for the hot dog buns too, but man, the hot dogs they bake into those things are so dried out and artificial, I'd be interested to know how much of it is actually meat. They have some good cakes, though. Their fruit tart was very good, and they also have a chocolate/cream cheese thing they sell by the register that kind of looks like a cream cheese brownie, which was really good. 

They have a few tables and seats at this place, so you can hang out and really enjoy those buns you just bought. Not too shabby.
author: Saunders C.

description: I don't remember eating here what-so-ever.  But I remember it well enough to write a review.  Amazing stuff.  Get the chocolate croissant.   I guess it was good, because I bought one.
author: Ahn E.

description: a little pricier than some other bakeries in the area, but it's significantly cleaner, and has a great selection of delicious pasteries and buns. The variety of options beats any of the other bakeries in the area. The price difference of about .50 per pastry is worth it when you can get everything you want in one place.
author: Angela O.

description:
Looks pretty, tastes bland. Every dessert I bought here sucked. Not as bad as Tart to Tart, but not worth the calories and diabetes. I don't understand why is it so difficult to get a decent dessert place in the inner sunset? Disappointing.

In short: Meh
author: Dorkus A.

description: Never once I come to this Sheng Kee and get good service. I have been getting cakes and buns from this location many times, and the ladies that work there always talk to me (and others) as if we done something wrong and deserved to be yelled at. I don't expect an awesome service, but at least don't yell and give me the attitude. I am not expecting an improvement, and I don't need to shop there neither.
author: Cindy C.

description: great atmosphere. helpful workers. We loved Portuguese tart. Would highly recommend because it is close to 9th and Judah.
author: Bob D.

description: Their cakes look so thick and tasty but literally the cake is all air. Very light and no taste at all. Even the icing loses flavor. I don't know about their bread though. I only came once because I saw their display of cakes since its right in front of the doorway when you pass by.
author: Natalie Charlotte W.

description: This is a fairly standard Sheng Kee outpost that offers a variety of freshly baked and affordable Chinese/Taiwanese pastries, including green onion rolls (think Chinese-style ciabatta rolls, which were a childhood staple of mine), "pineapple" rolls (the bread has a pineapple-looking, crispy custard topping, but does not taste like pineapple -- yes, very confusing, I know), and a wide variety of seasonal moon cakes (which Chinese/Taiwanese people eat in the fall to celebrate the mid-autumn festival).  They also serve Peet's coffee here and have some very affordable meal combinations (e.g., breaded chicken cutlet sandwich with milk tea and tapioca pearls for under $4).  All in all, this is a solid Sheng Kee location with plenty of tasty treats and cafeteria-style seating and wifi (complete with cafeteria-like charm).
author: Chris T.

description: Not too shabby and its more of a self serve pick and pay go type of place. Its great for baked goods that are mainly Chinese inspired. Reasonable prices on most items and nicely done.
author: R C.

description: I am in love with this place! I finally found a good bubble tea... Everywhere else in this city the milk teas make me want to throw up but their coconut milk tea is delicious and kudos to them for some very creative pastries! Bacon croissant?? Hells yes
author: Francesca H.

description: There was a little confusion when I came in to order the new Honey Toast because the girl had no idea what I was talking about and she told me they didn't offer it.  I saw a gigantic poster of it outside and had to show her then she had to ask someone but after all that it was smooth sailing!  It's about a 30 minute wait for it but SOOOO worth it!! It's is a hollowed out half loaf of toast filled with the toast that was hollowed out of it cubed and toasted with honey then filled with custard, fruits, and topped with ice cream... YUM! Drooling just thinking about it.  Since there was a 30 minute wait, and we were hungry we also picked out some pastries and breads that were delish too.  The garlic bread and pesto bread is very flavorful.  The german pudding tart is really good too!  They have milk tea and coffee drinks with illy coffee.  The set up is different from other Sheng Kees that I have been to but similar to a lot of new bakeries around.  The kitchen is open so you can watch them bake pastries.  There are a few tables to sit in the back and a bathroom right outside.  I will definitely be back for the honey toast!
author: Kymberli C.

description: I LOVE their Tiger Milk Tea with boba. They do a great job with their boba. As someone who makes boba at home, I think their tapioca pearls are great!!
author: Adele G.

description:
Last couple days, I have been listening news radio without my taste Whitney Houston over and over, and I was very tired hearing,
"ANDHAHHHHH, EAHHHHHH, EAHHHHHHH, I always FXXX Yooooooooo."
FXXX.
Enough is enough.

So, I stop listen the news radio and listening some bossa nova in stead.

Etta James passed away too you know, couple weeks ago. But people were very quiet. I wonder why. I liked her much more, and I can listen her voice again and again but Whitney Houston. 

Difference between Etta and Whitney is like Chinatown bakery and this Sheng Kee.

This Sheng Kee has no old-style pork bun or chicken bun.
In stead, they have shit like this:
Hawaii Bun, pineapple, corn, ham and cheese on it. $1.75
I was like, "Really? Are you FXXXin' serious? What kinda Fxxxed-up thing is this?"
I didn't say that. But my face was.
There was a super-nice thin and fit "gay-side" Asian man look at me, and may be read my mind, said, "Oh! that's my favorite!"
The way he said "FAVORITE" was that there was an extension voice, I don't know how to write the way he said, but it sounded like "FAhhhy-vorytt"
Do you know the sound?
That sounds pretty gay isn't it?
Hey, Stop! 
Don't get me wrong here, I am not a Mormon, I say No to Prop 8.
I am just describing and giving you a clear information. That is it.
Also, there was a totally Chinatown kind of middle age lady listening and she said the same thing. 
"The Hawaii Bun is my favorite too!"
So, I got one.
The lady said, "Just one? it's fresh baked!"
Yeah, she was super nice too.

Do you like Super-Nice-Asian-People?
S.N.A.P.
You always got to be careful any S.N.A.P.

So, I got 2 Hawaii Buns. I really didn't  know what the Fxxx I'm eating. It tasted nothin' but piece of shit.
And I got 1 hot dog cheese bun, sorry to say but I had better.
and 1 poteto salad bun. it's OK.

What attract here is that Euro-style very clean store. But this kind of bakery reminds me of 80's in Japan. I remember that there were so many Euro-style bakeries almost every where in Japan.
So, I would say this. This is Euro-style-Japonized Bakery.

All buns were not too great.
It's cheap.
But, that's about it.
After eating a Hawaii Bun, I was like:
"ANDHAHHHHH, EAHHHHHH, EAHHHHHHH, you always FXXX me up."
FXXXed up my stomach.
Enough is enough.

How about the other Hawaii Bun? It went straight into a street corner garbage can on Irving Street with NO hesitation!

I got compliments!!!
Yey!

Jessica C. said, "why did you not get a pineapple custard bun? those are the shit! also the portuguese egg tart."

Ken K. said, "I think I'm one of few people who understand what you mean! Sheng Kee is neither authentic Hong Kong nor authentic Japanese influenced Taiwanese, but incorporates elements from both, and leans more towards Taiwanese. The buns and breads are average, maybe sub par compared to Southern California Taiwanese bakery. You probably prefer butaman, anpan, melon pan and something like Clover Bakery in San Jose :-). I think sausage bun here would be at most what I would get. WTF is a Hawaii bun though."

Lolia S. said, " I know the guy you're talking about, ha ha "
author: Nobu K.

description: Fairly good bakery with lots of options at fantastic prices. Bakery items are Chinese-influenced. So expect egg tarts, char siew pastry and HK-style buns. Come for a cheap lunch but most of all, order the $1.99 ham & egg bun with a medium bubble tea deal.
author: Kwoky L.

description:
3.25 stars? Yeah, around there. It's not a bad bakery at all.  It's on the better side. It reminds me of 85 degree bakery back in SoCal but much smaller and less crowded. I would definitely come back again and again for pastries at this place and the main reason is that it is CHEAP, cheaper than 85 degree bakery and it is walking distance from UCSF campus. If you are a broke-ass grad student, trying to find good deals in the area, then you can't go wrong with this; they have weekly specials ranging from 99cent boba drinks to $3 pastries with a free boba drink. They have those specials every week so there is always a good deal every time you enter the bakery. 

Besides hakuna matata, my motto is quality over quantity. They have a great variety and quantity of pastries, which is great but quality control is the main issue. Some of their pastries are too sweet and soggy. I'm a sweet tooth and that's saying something! Ironically, the boba drinks might be on the bland side so always ask the cashier about your sweetness preference. They basically need to reevaluate the proportions they use during their baking process.

Oh and if you still can't make up your mind, get the milk cream bread. It's good.

T-rx
author: Mark Y.

description: Friend bought me a birthday cake here and it was very good -- mango and raspberry. Very light and not too sweet. I would love to get another cake from here. Yum.
author: Vicki T.

description: Huge variety, fresh and flavorful mousse!  The staff is very friendly and helpful.
author: Kenyon S.

description: I do like the cakes here.  They are not too sweet and the cake is fluffy and light.  I especially like the cake with fruit in them.  They also sell sandwiches and baked goods.  This location is great for other shopping and boba cravings around the  neighborhood.
author: Jennie W.

description: Got the Sweet Potato Bun covered in powdered sugar for about $1.60. It was alright, nothing special. The bun was HUGE and mochi-mochi soft, but I couldn't reach the filling until like 1/2 way through the monster, and it wasn't really very flavorful. It had a warm bread taste to it but all the sweetness came from the sugar on top. Its so big the only way to really eat it is to stuff your mouth and throat with powdered sugar and bread and it wasn't terribly pleasant. You have to open your jaw super wide too, unless you squish it first. I felt like I had powdered sugar all over my face, hair, and clothes for the rest of the day. Don't get me wrong, it wasn't a bad pastry, it just really wasn't anything special.
author: Alice R.

description: A very "Americanized" Chinese bakery, but still very good. I love their Thai Iced Tea with Boba. They also have a wide selection of baked good. Yesterday, I bought a cake with a panda bear face, and it was great. It looked very nice, and tasted delicious. Nice place, and the prices are very low compared to others.
author: Nikita K.

description: If you love your buns, pastries, and what not, I highly reccomend this spot! I almost always go here during break or after work from Jamba Juice. Place is clean and you pick and choose which pieces you want. I always get the hawaiian bun and pork bun, which both come to only about three bucks, talk about cheap! Staff is friendly as well and is willing to help make suggestions if you aren't exactly sure what you want to get.
author: Stephen B.

description: Among all its chain stores, it is my favorite.  Clean. Good customer services. Variety of selection with reasonable price.
author: Lynn Y.

description:
Came here on a cold day and ordered a hot HK milk tea, they just poured it out of their container that's supposed to keep it hot but it totally wasn't.  I've ordered it before and they made it hot, but I guess service at Chinese establishments aren't known for consistency as I was overcharged triple for a slice of cake that the 4 eyed girl thought was called something else.  
It gets worse, one of the idiot Chinese worker guy from the kitchen goes and props open the back door making it extremely cold.  I don't think they do this on hot days when it's needed.  I probably won't be going back unless I feel like sh*t and want to talk to idiots who can't understand English but love overcharging me and making me feel unwelcomed.  
What's the deal with the plastic tongs never being washed but put back on the display? Doesn't bacteria breed in only a few hours?  If they do get attention, it's a quick wipe with a rag they used on a table.  I guess hygiene in a bakery is overrated.
author: Ken K.

description: It's cute! Employees are super-sweet. Free wifi. Good for snacking.
author: Deb T.

description:
This place is a 4.5 mile walk one way from my apartment and it's STILL making me fat! I cannot buy one item from here. I always end up with at least 2 and wanting more. It's very different from my formerly favorite bakery, Arizmendi, in that stuff here is chockful of ingredients you shouldn't be eating -refined white flour, margarine, processed meats- but I sure do love the taste and the friendly workers (and the fact that the crowd is nothing like the somewhat privileged, entitled crowd at Arizmendi). 

Prices here are ridiculously cheap, and the garlic bread rectangle thing makes me want to keep eating them til I can't move. I even tried the tuna donut. Odd, but not that bad. Aptly described by dining partner as a tuna piroshki. 

I think the garlic cheese bread is better than Andersen's as it's less greasy and less money. The sponge cake roll slices ($.99!), are tasty, and so is most of what else I've tried, with the exception of the dried pork bun. That was odd.

My favorites are definitely the bread items with garlic. Yum! Yes they are greasy and salty, and that's what makes them so good!
author: Allucaneat G.

description: I always come here for delicious and beautifully decorated cakes.  It's light and fluffy, variety of both fruit and chocolate flavors.  Not decadently or overwhelmingly sweet.  So light and fluffy, you can eat more than 1 slice!
author: JJAMZ C.

description:
Flavorless.

Overpriced

South-facing storefronts should not have food in the windows.  The hot, piercing sun is shining on the baked goods (some with cheese) .... it's a good thing this place is near UCSF hospital.

I bought some sort of puff pastry "shredded pork" thingamajig and it was tasteless. The "meat" was literally like sawdust.  Gross. I wasted $1.85

I ate 3 bites then tossed it into the garbage can.

The place is clean, has friendly staff, in a convenient location... hardly enough to make me return. I want TASTY treats at bakeries.

Instead I headed for the nearby donut shop and got a damn good (fresh and tasty) donut for just 90 cents.

Sorry folks..but just not worth a return visit.
author: Scott T.

description: Love Love Love their fresh strawberry cake!!! OMG I eat the whole thing every freakin' time!!!
author: Serina H.

description: We got these churro looking things.  They didn't taste like churros.
author: Audrey K.

description: Very chill relaxed spot to go pick up a pastry on the fly. Prices are really cheap. Their shredded pork bun was incredible. Just be sure to check the ingredients to make sure for mayo (they put globs of it on the inside). Staff is friendly it's a clean place and again super affordable if you're on the go! One other thing.. there's a $5 minimum for cards! The pastries (cakes/cheesecakes) are around $3 each which is incredibly awesome!
author: Lissette L.

description:
Amazing. Just amazing.

This place reminds me very much of the bakery i used to have growing up in Taiwan. It would be great if they could have more variety.
author: J P.

description: So many good things here! The mixed berry flan/custard tart was my favorite!!
author: Katherine S.

description: Sing Kee does not have good service, they wrap the pastry in a nice bag, but the box is like a shoe or gift box that is from the post office. They use to have those nice orange boxes but I guest they are trying to save money. There service is bad. Pastry is okay, but toward the end of the day the pastry are hard.
author: Roy G.

description: I tried their cocktail bun and red bean bun about a month ago, and they both had no flavor and overpriced. Sheng Kee is the equivalent to Starbucks is to coffee, both are chains and trying to beat out the little guy while trying to sell overpriced goods and don't care about quality. I've tasted better cocktail buns in Chinatown for 3 times less than what Sheng Kee charges. Let's see a tasty cocktail bun for 40-50cents in Chinatown or a bland cocktail bun which they sell as a pair for A dollar thirty five. I think I will stick with Chinatown.
author: Lawrence F.

description:
one day i was craving for some cakes so i went to sheng kee.
i picked a green tea & red bean paste swiss roll and was looking for the expiration date. i checked all the the rolls and none of them had the date on the packages.
therefore i took one to the cashier and ask about it.
i think the cashier was new so she went to asked her coworker about the expiration date.
the guy said, there is no expiration date.
then i asked, so how do i know how long this lasts?
the guys said, 3 days maybe?
after his asnwer i put the roll back and walked out of the store.
I can understand bakeries dont always have the expiration date on all the products
but if you seal, and well pack, i expect seeing expiration dates on what I get.
author: Tin K.

description: This bakery is good. I got my red bean donut and creme filled pastry and was sold on this place. I loved the layout of the breads, and pastry.  The milk tea is a steal.  This is the place. After a disappointing dinner this made it up.
author: Drew C.

description: The name got me in the door...was it a bakery that made rolls like what I had in Taiwan? Not sure I found those, but I was in flaky, crusty, carbohydrate heaven. The selection!! The reasonable prices!! The flavor!! Thank god I don't live in SF or morbid obesity would be knocking at my door. Looking forward very much to being in this neighborhood again!
author: Deborah R.

description: I don't understand why people don't seem to like this place.  I am just so happy to have a delicious taro bun in walking distance.
author: Cork C.

description:
I used to be an Arizmendi fan, but their Chocolate Things have become way more dough than chocolate (used to be the other way around) and more expensive too.  So I checked out Sheng Kee down the street and around the corner.  This place is dangerous.  Really good pastries and very reasonably priced.  I'm not quite courageous enough to try what look like treats made out of thick slices of white bread, but fat and carbs are available in lots of different forms here.  I'm relieved I don't live in this neighborhood because I can resist anything except temptation, but when I do have work in the Inner Sunset I'm at this bakery every friggin day.

That said, there are a couple of drawbacks.  The cafe area with the tables and chairs is painted hospital-green that induces feelings of nausea.  Best to get your goods and go.

Also when they are busy service suffers (folks behind you will get rung up before you), so avoid coming during busy times.
author: Susan B.

description:
Great place. This location definitely offers a slightly different variety than their other Irving Street location. It is obviously still an Asian style bakery but with more unique type pastries (savory & sweet). LOVED their yam bun...a soft sweet bun filled with a sweet yam paste. Very light and not overly sweet. Portuguese custard tarts are excellent, creamy but not too egg-y. And their "toast" with sugar and butter is sooo yummy in a decadent way. Lots of other things have yet to try...taro buns, croissants, cocktail buns etc.
Also beware..if you want any buns with pork in them some of them are the more traditional type pork bun pork (very moist) BUT if they say  "SHREDDED dry pork" then that's what you're going to get. It's dry..very dry and salty. Some folks like that...I do not. Overall, very yummy place. Can't wait to try all of their other items!
author: rosie t.

description:
I've been a Sheng Kee customer for years, not exactly by choice but more because it caters to my family's chinese taste buds. Mom and I (and my aunties) frequent the outer sunset location quite a bit since we're always grocery shopping in the area. I've never really liked any of their stuff, but it did the job in terms of quelling my hunger pains.  One item of theirs I do LIKE is their chocolate pineapple bun! YUM! sometimes I'll walk the 20 some odd blocks from my house just for that bun. MMMMMMM

The 9th and Irving location popped up and surprised me. It's much closer to my house, and the items somehow are much tastier than the other locations. The biggest difference though is the workers here are actually friendly and happy to help and answer any questions. CUSTOMER SERVICE IN A CHINESE ESTABLISHMENT?!?!?! WHAAAAAAAAAAAAA?! I'm chinese and I've never heard of such a thing, unless I am with my white friends, hahahahaha. The items are I feel are a tad bit different from the other locations (perhaps catering to a different clientele?) but they also have a few similar items too, like the standard ham and corn bun, egg custard tart, pineapple bun, etc. (BUT WHERE IS MY CHOCO PINEAPPLE BUN?) I've tried the tomato danish, curry beef donut, blueberry loaf, and some other stuff I can't remember, and I haven't been disappointed at this location yet. It kind of reminds me of the popular 85 degrees taiwanese bakery in SOCAL, not quite as mind blowing but definitely close. 

I think this is going to be a regular stop from now on. Shorter walking distance for me, yummier than their other Irving (and other) locations and the staff is pretty awesome! OOOhhhhhh and they have two tables and a few chairs out front so you may sit and enjoy your goodies in the sun since 9th and Irving is one of the few places that gets constant sunshine in SF. I hope the owners bring my chocolate pineapple bun to this location....then I'll be here everyday! MMMMMMM
author: Gaile C.

description: I give this place 4 stars for the bread. Even though I've been to this bakery at least half a dozen times, I never noticed the loaves of bread sitting on the shelves above the pastries. Most of the pastries I've tried (taro bun, coconut bun, blueberry pound cake, sponge cake, strawberry cake, chocolate cake) have been really mediocre. The bread is where it's at. I like the half loaf of "sweet toast" - only costs a couple of bucks and makes delicious, chewy French toast. My favorite taro bun comes from 85 Degree Bakery - sorry Sheng Kee. But, I will come to Sheng Kee again and again for the loaves of bread.
author: Sophie L.

description: I've been getting pastries and cold subs in the Sheng Kee Bakery in outer sunset for the longest time, so I was pretty excited when this place opened up a few blocks from my house. However, I was pretty disappointed with what I saw when I came here. There are not nearly as much selections of pastries and the prices are a bit heavy for the portion. I usually just come here for their cold ready to go sandwiches, which are pretty good for only $3.19.
author: William C.

description: Why people are in love the sweets here is a mystery. I wish a really good bakery would open up in the Sunset. Arizmendi is not a good bakery except if you're into oraganic and Tart to Tart , although a neighborhood staple, isn't great. La Boulange might be coming  to 9th Ave though and that is good.
author: brian d.

description: I like this place. Stuff is always friendly. The place is clean. A lot of delicious things for any gourmand.
author: Lola B.

description: Dayum so so goood! It's breakfast time at work now and I am so hungry thinking about this place. I was in Inner Sunset for the day and was checking out a lot of places, this being one of them. I had just pigged out at Curry Village buffet yet when i walked in I wanted to buy everything in sight. Of course I would be even poorer since they have a LOT of food stuff! I had also gone into another bakery on 9th, don't remember the name, but their items were your average muffins, donuts, etc. BORING. This bakery has a lot of other exciting things like custard pies, fruit sticks.. oh geesh I don't even remember their names because I remember by the way they look.. and they looked GOOD haha. I did buy two custard pies.. um Armani pie or sumthin? Another one with blueberry. I got pineapple stick. A strawberry custard bun. And some special cookies with red bean inside. So I didn't eat any of them there.. but dude I pigged out at home for dinner! O.M.G! Everything was soo sooo good. I wanna live next to this bakery waah I can't wait to go back!
author: Vol T.

description:
nice bread, yummy swiss rolls, but very standard asian bakery with bad service. 

i would probably go there more often if the people working there are not so painfully rude.
author: Kiki Y.

description: Yet another Chinese bakery chain, with all the pros and cons that come with the territory.  Prices are super-reasonable - massive cupcakes and generous cake slices for $1.95.  On the other hand, you get what you pay for.  Tried the pineapple raisin cream bun, which had a hollow interior lined with a strange sugary paste and a smattering of raisins, as well as slice of mango cake, which was refreshing but not as airy as similar variants from higher-end bakeries.
author: Jeremy C.

description: I didn't know there was a Sheng Kee Bakery this far on Irving, but I was in the area and craving a custard tart so I popped in.  I bought a Portuguese custard because the other ones looked burned and gross.  I also bought an apple tart and I should have not purchased it because it was really heavy to pick up with the tongs, and that should have been an indication that it was not the tasty dessert I was planning on having.  The Portuguese custard was okay, but it was missing some sweetness.  Maybe that's what makes it different than regular custard; I don't know.  When I went to the counter to pay, the lady who works there had just touched the trash can because it fell.  Then she touched the money.  Then she touched my pastries and threw them into a paper bag when I said I wanted them to go.  She didn't even bother to put them into separate bags like they do at the other Sheng Kee Bakery and the apple tart was kind of crushed.  I also wasn't thrilled that they were touching each other in the bag.  Her rudeness on top of the burned custard warrants this place two stars.
author: k h.
